symptoms: Neurodevelopmental disorder with hearing loss and spasticity
comment: KCTD1 is a gene that has been linked to several rare genetic disorders, including Gillessen-Kaesbach-Nishimura syndrome and Craniofacial-deafness-hand syndrome. These conditions are characterized by a range of symptoms, including developmental delays, hearing loss, and physical abnormalities.

The gene NCF1 is associated with various physical and developmental abnormalities, including dysmetria. Dysmetria refers to a lack of coordination and balance, which can manifest in different ways in individuals with this condition.

The gene SLC34A3 is associated with hypophosphatemic rickets, calcium nephrolithiasis, and medullary nephrocalcinosis. The symptoms and abnormalities linked to this gene include bowing of the legs, widely patent fontanelles and sutures, metaphyseal irregularity, enlargement of the wrists and ankles, thin bony cortex, deformed rib cage, hyperphosphaturia, renal phosphate wasting, rachitic rosary, and hypophosphatemia.
STING1 gene is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and other autoimmune diseases.
The EDARADD gene is a master regulator of tooth development. Mutations in this gene have been associated with anodontia, a condition characterized by the absence of all permanent teeth.
The GFM1 gene is associated with Fulminant Hepatic Failure and Basal Ganglia Cysts. Further research is needed to understand the exact nature of this relationship.
GPI stands for Glucose-6-Phosphate Isomerase, which is an enzyme involved in glycolysis.
CPT1A gene provides instructions for making an enzyme called carnitine palmitoyltransferase 1A, which plays a role in the breakdown of fatty acids.

comment: CFHR5 gene mutation is associated with a range of kidney diseases including MPGN, DDD, and MN. The symptoms and abnormalities listed are characteristic of these conditions.

A gene mutation or alteration in the TEKT3 gene has been associated with these abnormalities and diseases, leading to various symptoms such as abnormal sperm physiology, acrosomal hypoplasia, and multiple non-erupting secondary teeth.

UGT1A1 is a gene that provides instructions for making an enzyme called uridine diphosphate glucuronyltransferase 1A1. This enzyme plays a crucial role in the conjugation of bilirubin, a byproduct of red blood cell breakdown. Mutations in the UGT1A1 gene can lead to Crigler-Najjar Syndrome Type II, which is characterized by severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Variations in the MBL2 gene have been associated with an increased risk of developing certain infections and diseases. The gene provides instructions for making a protein called mannose-binding lectin, which plays a key role in the immune system's ability to recognize and respond to pathogens. Variants of the MBL2 gene have been linked to impaired immune function, leading to an increased susceptibility to certain infections.
MID1 gene mutations have been associated with various abnormalities and diseases, including the ones mentioned above.
The CRB2 gene is associated with Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, a type of nephrotic syndrome that affects the kidneys.

comment: The UBE3A gene is associated with the regulation of sleep-wake cycles. Mutations or alterations in this gene have been linked to shortened sleep phase syndrome, a condition characterized by an irregular sleep-wake cycle. The symptoms and diseases related to UBE3A include impaired sleep-wake cycle, fatigue, and increased risk of diabetes and cardiovascular disease.

The DUX4 gene is associated with Pure mitochondrial myopathy, a rare genetic disorder that affects the mitochondria, leading to symptoms such as scapular winging.

The MAP2K1 gene provides instructions for making a protein called mitogen-activated protein kinase 1, which plays a crucial role in regulating the activity of certain proteins involved in cellular signaling pathways. Mutations or changes in this gene have been linked to various diseases and abnormalities, including Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis and Abnormal intermamillary distance.
BRG1 is a gene that provides instructions for making a protein called BRG1. This protein plays a role in the regulation of gene expression and chromatin remodeling.

Mutations in NOTCH3 have been associated with non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy, a condition that affects the blood vessels supplying the optic nerve and can lead to visual field defects, optic atrophy, and visual loss.

symptoms: Hypoplasia of the inferior cerebellar vermis
comment: MED11 is a gene that encodes a protein involved in histone chaperone function. Mutations in MED11 have been associated with various disorders, including dysgyria, inferior cerebellar vermis hypoplasia, limb joint contracture, and exaggerated startle response.
The association of ZNF699 with chronic kidney disease suggests that the gene may play a role in the development or progression of the disease.

diseases: Abnormality of tumor necrosis factor secretion
Abnormality of multiple cell lineages in the bone marrow
symptoms: Abnormality of tumor necrosis factor secretion symptoms
Abnormality of the coagulation cascade symptoms
Abnormality of multiple cell lineages in the bone marrow symptoms
Abnormal natural killer cell physiology symptoms
comment: UNC13D is a gene that has been associated with various immune-related disorders. The exact function of this gene is not fully understood, but it is believed to play a role in regulating the activity of certain immune cells.
CTNNA2 gene mutations have been associated with both LIPN and Elastosis perforans serpiginosa.
The EBF3 gene is associated with myopathy, a congenital muscle disorder. It also affects the shape of the face, causing an oval facial appearance.
PIGTA gene mutations are associated with PIGT syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to produce glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchors.

The DYRK1A gene is associated with various abnormalities and diseases, including abnormal axial skeleton morphology, posterior pituitary dysgenesis, and abnormal optic chiasm morphology. It is also linked to abnormal posterior pituitary morphogenesis.

diseases: Edema of the dorsum of hands
symptoms: edema of the dorsum of hands
comment: KLHL40 gene mutations are associated with a range of clinical conditions, including skeletal abnormalities and muscle disorders.
the gene is associated with both conditions which are characterized by abnormal metabolism of the amino acid adipic acid.

symptoms: Elevated levels of 3-hydroxyglutaric acid in urine
comment: GCDH stands for Glutaryl-CoA Dehydrogenase, a gene that plays a crucial role in the metabolism of certain amino acids. Mutations in this gene have been linked to various neurological disorders and abnormalities.

ZNF408 is a transcription factor gene that has been associated with several retinal disorders. The specific association between ZNF408 and the listed symptoms, abnormalities, and diseases suggests that this gene plays a critical role in the development and maintenance of retinal tissue.

diseases: Abnormal morphology of the vestibule of the inner ear
symptoms: Abnormal morphology of the vestibule of the inner ear
comment: EBF3 gene is associated with a variety of developmental and congenital abnormalities, including those related to the face, hearing, and bladder function. The exact mechanisms of how EBF3 influences these traits are not yet fully understood.

The ATL1 gene is associated with a range of neurological disorders, including Focal Segmental Dysplasia and Periventricular Leukoencephalopathy (PVL). It has also been linked to Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML) and dysplastic gangliocytosis. The symptoms associated with ATL1 include slow motor conduction, impaired ability to dress oneself, limb pain, trophic changes related to pain, and neuropathic arthropathy.

ROBO3 is a gene that encodes for the receptor tyrosine kinase ROBO3, which plays a crucial role in the development and function of the immune system. Mutations or aberrant expression of this gene have been associated with autoimmune diseases such as RHD and AIHA.
CFAP91 gene is associated with microcephalic sperm head (MCH) and macrozoospermia, two male reproductive health issues. The gene plays a role in the development and function of sperm cells.

diseases: Abnormality of the autonomic nervous system
comment: The gene MYO1H is associated with a group of disorders that affect the esophagus and gastrointestinal tract, leading to symptoms such as dysphagia, regurgitation, and aspiration pneumonia.
SETBP1 gene mutations are associated with Generalized Hypertrichosis and Cataract-Deafness-Hypogonadism Syndrome.

The DICER1 gene is a tumor suppressor gene that, when mutated or deleted, can lead to an increased risk of developing various types of cancer and tumors. The associations listed above indicate that the DICER1 gene is linked to a range of different diseases and conditions, including rare cancers such as pleuropulmonary blastoma and embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma.

symptoms: Delayed brainstem auditory evoked response conduction time
prader-willi syndrome due to imprinting mutation
comment: SHOX gene provides instructions for making a protein called sex-determining region Y protein (SRY) box H-containing protein X, which is involved in the development of bones and cartilage.
EFHC1 is a gene associated with photosensitive tonic-clonic seizures, epilepsy, spastic diplegia, and mental retardation.
The MBL2 gene provides instructions for making the mannose-binding lectin protein, which plays a crucial role in the immune system's ability to fight off pathogens.

diseases: Neurofibromatosis type 1 due to NF1 mutation or intragenic deletion
Microcephalic osteodysplastic primordial dwarfism, type I
comment: The gene RNU4ATAC is a small nuclear RNA that plays a crucial role in various cellular processes, including translation, splicing, and DNA repair. Mutations in this gene have been associated with multiple congenital disorders and diseases.

diseases: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis 22 with or without frontotemporal dementia
Autosomal dominant generalized dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa
Localized dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa, acral form
Autosomal recessive generalized epidermolysis bullosa simplex
Hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathy type 2
Epidermolysis bullosa simplex, generalized, with scarring and hair loss
Silver-Russell syndrome due to maternal uniparental disomy of chromosome 11
comment: H19 gene is a non-coding RNA that plays a role in growth and development. Mutations or abnormalities in the H19 gene have been linked to several diseases and syndromes, including Silver-Russell syndrome.
A gene that causes hereditary retinitis pigmentosa, a group of rare genetic disorders that affect the retina's ability to respond to light.
Note: The association between RNU7-1 and Interferon-gamma mediated disorders is a direct association, however the actual gene underlying Aicardi-Goutires syndrome has not been determined yet.

diseases: Abnormal left ventricular outflow tract morphology

comment: - The association of IL12A with venous thrombosis may suggest a possible role in the regulation of blood coagulation or inflammation.

diseases: Atrioventricular defect-blepharophimosis-radial and anal defect syndrome
symptoms: Atrioventricular defect-blepharophimosis-radial and anal defect syndrome
comment: [[The gene LMBR1 encodes a protein involved in limb development, and mutations in this gene have been associated with aplasia cutis congenita and other limb abnormalities.]]

SLC25A22 gene mutations are linked to combined oxidative phosphorylation deficiency 46 (COD46) and PET117. COD46 is a rare genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to generate energy, while PET117 is a variant of COD46.

symptoms: Abnormal CSF branched chain amino acid concentration
comment: The BCKDHA gene provides instructions for making the branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase complex, an enzyme that plays a crucial role in breaking down certain amino acids (branched-chain amino acids)

The CDC73 gene is associated with Brugada syndrome, a heart condition characterized by abnormal electrocardiogram (ECG) patterns and an increased risk of sudden cardiac death. It also has a link to shortened QT intervals.
involved in the persistence of fetal hemoglobin

diseases: Inflammatory skin and bowel disease, neonatal
Neuropathy, hereditary sensory and autonomic, type II

symptoms: Absent or minimally ossified vertebral bodies
Absent in utero ossification of vertebral bodies
comment: BMPER gene mutation is associated with a range of skeletal dysplasias and related disorders.

diseases: X-linked intellectual disability-hypotonia-facial dysmorphism-aggressive behavior syndrome
Epilepsy, X-linked 2, with or without impaired intellectual development and dysmorphic features
Mental retardation, x-linked syndromic, Raymond type
comment: MYMX gene is linked to multiple genetic disorders and diseases, including Bartter syndrome type 4, intellectual developmental disorder, X-linked intellectual disability-hypotonia-facial dysmorphism-aggressive behavior syndrome, Birk-Barel syndrome, 15q13.3 microdeletion syndrome, Bloom syndrome, Fragile X syndrome, Snijders Blok-Fisher syndrome, Cold-Induced sweating syndrome 2, 3-M syndrome 3, Epilepsy, X-linked 2, with or without impaired intellectual development and dysmorphic features, Trichothiodystrophy 8, nonphotosensitive, X-linked microcephaly-growth retardation-prognathism-cryptorchidism syndrome, Osteoglosphonic dysplasia, Autosomal dominant primary microcephaly, Cleft lip/palate-ectodermal dysplasia syndrome, Mental retardation, x-linked syndromic, Raymond type, Corpus callosum agenesis-abnormal genitalia syndrome.

diseases: Impaired growth-hormone response to glucagon stimulation test

comment: POMGnH gene mutations lead to reduced muscle fiber alpha-dystroglycan, a key component of the muscle cell's basement membrane. This results in muscular dystrophy and limb-girdle muscular dystrophy.
The gene FBXW11 is linked to several abnormalities and diseases, including joint contractures and eye alignment issues.

diseases: PRKAR1B-related neurodegenerative dementia with intermediate filaments
comment: This gene is associated with PRKAR1B-related neurodegenerative dementia with intermediate filaments. The symptoms of this disease include neurodegenerative dementia.
The KNG1 gene provides instructions for making the protein kininogen 1, which plays a crucial role in the regulation of blood clotting.

The PSMD9 gene is linked to Succinic-CoA Coenzyme A Ligase Deficiency and Type II Mitochondrial Myopathies, which are characterized by abnormal circulating enzyme concentrations and reduced peroxisomal glutaryl-CoA oxidase activity.
LID1 (lysosomal idioglycosyl lipid phosphatase) is the gene that codes for the protein involved in these diseases. Corneal opacity is a common symptom among many of these conditions.

RNU4ATAC is a gene that has been associated with multiple diseases and conditions, including Wiskott-aldrich Syndrome, Autosomal erythropoietic protoporphyria, Paget disease, extramammary, and Eczematoid dermatitis. The symptoms and abnormalities linked to this gene include skin blistering, anemia, thrombocytopenia, nephritis, skeletal abnormalities, neurological symptoms, photosensitivity, pigmentary deposits in the skin, and alopecia.

STX5 gene is involved in the development of the heart and blood vessels. Mutations or alterations in this gene have been associated with abnormal fetal cardiovascular physiology and persistent patent ductus venosus, a condition where the ductus arteriosus, a blood vessel that connects the pulmonary artery to the aorta, fails to close after birth.

The CFTR gene is a critical gene that codes for the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator protein. Mutations in this gene are associated with cystic fibrosis, which can cause abnormal bone growth and development, including delayed bone age.

symptoms: Abnormality of the middle phalanx of the 5th finger
comment: FTND1 is a gene associated with Acromesomalia, a rare genetic disorder that affects the growth and development of bones in the body. The symptoms listed are commonly associated with this condition.

diseases: bone marrow arrest at the promyelocytic stage
symptoms: absent microvilli on the surface of peripheral blood lymphocytes
comment: The gene DSPP is associated with Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome (WAS) and its related HP (Hypersplenism) type

Family Cutis Laxa (FLCN) is a genetic disorder that affects the skin, lungs, and other organs. Mutations in the FLCN gene are associated with Pneumothorax, a type of lung disease where air leaks into the space between the lungs and chest cavity.

diseases: Familial Giant Hypertrophic Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PH)
comment: The ABCC6 gene is associated with an autosomal recessive disorder that affects the reabsorption of cromolyn sodium in the lungs, leading to vascular dilatation and pulmonary hypertension. It also increases the risk of gastritis.
TMEM127 is a gene associated with Pheochromocytoma-Islet cell tumor syndrome, which can cause symptoms such as pheochromocytoma and islet cell tumors.

The AIRE gene is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes an enzyme involved in the regulation of immune tolerance. Mutations or aberrant expression of the AIRE gene have been linked to various autoimmune diseases, including Autoimmune gastritis, Type 1 diabetes, and celiac disease.
SH2B1 is the gene that encodes a protein involved in insulin signaling and glucose metabolism. Mutations in this gene have been linked to Severe early-onset obesity-insulin resistance syndrome.
The gene SDHAF1 is linked to Abnormal left ventricular function and Autoimmune hypoparathyroidism
Autophagy-related 9 gene (ALG9) mutations cause a range of developmental and morphological abnormalities.
PNPO gene mutations are linked to Hypoargininemia, a disorder that affects the metabolism of the amino acid arginine.

diseases: Abnormal brain glutamine level by MRS
Reduced brain glutamine level by MRS
High myoinositol in brain by MRS
comment: NGLY1 gene mutations are associated with a range of symptoms and diseases, including developmental delays, seizures, and vision loss. The exact mechanisms behind these effects are not fully understood but may involve disruptions in normal metabolic pathways involving the N-acetylaspartylglutamate (NAAG) neurotransmitter system.
The gene PKHD1 is associated with Polycystic Kidney Disease Type 1 and Congenital Megacalycosis. The symptoms listed are commonly reported in individuals with this genetic disorder.

symptoms: Recurrent shingles symptoms: pain, rash, blisters
Pericentral scotoma symptoms: blind spot loss, visual disturbances
Bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia symptoms: coughing, shortness of breath, wheezing

diseases: Increased theta frequency activity in EEG
comment: KCNT1 gene mutations are associated with a range of neurological symptoms and disorders. Mutations in KCNT1 have been linked to various forms of epilepsy, including generalized-onset motor seizure and focal seizures. Additionally, individuals with KCNT1 mutations may experience psychotic mentation, autonomic dysfunction, and other cognitive impairments.

DCXR and Pentosuria are related but distinct conditions. DCXR is a rare genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to break down certain sugars, while Pentosuria is a benign condition characterized by the excretion of L-xylulose in the urine.
NLRP3 is a gene that encodes for a protein called NLRP3, which is involved in the innate immune response. It has been associated with several diseases and symptoms listed above.
[LMOD2]

symptoms: Bilateral tonic-clonic seizure with generalized onset
comment: FBN1 is a gene that encodes for the protein fibrillin-1, which is important in the formation of elastic fibers found in connective tissue. Mutations in this gene have been linked to Marfan syndrome and other disorders.

The PRR12 gene is associated with Torus palatinus, a type of bony protrusion on the roof of the mouth. Additionally, there is a link between this gene and the Microcornea-glaucoma-absent frontal sinuses syndrome, which is characterized by small corneas, glaucoma, and absent or underdeveloped frontal sinuses.
The PLAA gene is associated with Patau syndrome, a rare genetic disorder caused by trisomy 13. It affects multiple systems in the body, including the musculoskeletal system, nervous system, and eyes.
IL-2 receptor alpha subunit mutation can lead to impaired T cell activation and function.

diseases: Triangular shaped phalanges of the hand
Hypoplasia of the capital femoral epiphysis
Partial duplication of the distal phalanx of the hallux
Duplication of distal phalanx of toe
comment: CANT1 gene mutations are associated with a range of skeletal and musculoskeletal disorders, including CANT1-related disorders. The gene is involved in the regulation of chondrocyte differentiation and osteoblast function, and mutations can lead to abnormal bone growth, joint problems, and musculoskeletal issues.
SAMD9L is a gene associated with OSLAM syndrome, which is characterized by increased MCV, among other symptoms.
The LTC4S gene is linked to Leukotriene C4 synthase deficiency, a condition characterized by reduced circulating leukotriene C4 concentration.

The RB1 gene is a tumor suppressor gene that plays a crucial role in regulating the cell cycle and preventing cancer. Mutations or deletions of this gene have been linked to several types of cancer, including bladder neoplasm and pinealoma.

diseases: Diffuse swelling of cerebral white matter
symptoms: Abnormalities of the brain and nervous system
comment: HEPACAM gene mutations are associated with a range of developmental disorders, including lymphoid nodular hyperplasia, diffuse white matter abnormalities, megalencephaly, penile freckling, intestinal polyposis, Hurthle cell thyroid adenoma, and diffuse spongiform leukoencephalopathy. These conditions can affect the brain, nervous system, thyroid gland, intestines, and skin.

diseases: Exostosis of the external auditory canal
Abnormal branching pattern of left aortic arch
Abnormal branching pattern of the aortic arch
Left aortic arch with retroesophageal right subclavian artery
comment: IPO8 gene mutations can lead to a range of cardiovascular and musculoskeletal abnormalities, as well as certain reproductive issues.

NSMCE2 gene mutations are associated with various diseases and abnormalities, including glucose intolerance, hypogonadism, mental retardation, skeletal anomalies, skeletal dysplasia, and abducens palsy.

Mutations in CLDN16 are associated with hyperoxaluria type II, a rare genetic disorder characterized by excessive absorption of oxalate from the intestine, leading to kidney stone formation and other complications.

The GATA2 gene is a transcription factor that plays a crucial role in the development and function of various cells, including hematopoietic cells. Mutations or alterations in the expression of GATA2 have been linked to several diseases and abnormalities, including cervical neoplasia and abnormal total neutrophil count.
The NOTCH2 gene has been associated with distal amyotrophy, a symptom of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) type 9.

LHX4 is an X-linked gene that encodes a transcription factor involved in the regulation of pituitary development. Mutations in this gene can lead to panhypopituitarism, which includes symptoms such as growth hormone deficiency, gonadal dysgenesis, and sexual infantilism.
The BLOM gene is responsible for Bloom Syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by short stature, telangiectasias (dilated blood vessels), and an increased risk of cancer.

The DKC1 gene is associated with various developmental disorders and abnormalities, including Anal mucosal leukoplakia and Decreased pineal volume. However, more research is needed to fully understand the relationship between the DKC1 gene and these conditions.

The PERCC1 gene is associated with Weight loss in Perry syndrome, Choreoacanthocytosis, Primary Fanconi renotubular syndrome, Fatal familial insomnia, Gerstmann-Straussler disease, RIDDLE syndrome, Huntington disease, Anemia, sideroblastic, and spinocerebellar ataxia, Hereditary late-onset Parkinson disease, Huntington disease-like 2, Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1, Hereditary arginine vasopressin deficiency, Symptomatic form of HFE-related hemochromatosis, Hypercalcemia, infantile, 1, Isovaleric acidemia, Thyrotoxic periodic paralysis, susceptibility to, 1, Thyrotoxic periodic paralysis, susceptibility to, 2, Generalized pseudohypoaldosteronism type 1, Familial glucocorticoid deficiency, Caroli disease, Majeed syndrome, Budd-Chiari syndrome, Familial pancreatic carcinoma, Perry syndrome, Parkinson disease 4, Pulmonary alveolar microlithiasis, Congenital fiber-type disproportion myopathy, Multiple myeloma, Classic mycosis fungoides, Bullous pemphigoid, Neuroblastoma, susceptibility to, Hereditary pheochromocytoma-paraganglioma, Sporic pheochromocytoma/secreting paraganglioma, Familial gestational hyperthyroidism, Familial hyperthyroidism due to mutations in TSH receptor, Huntington disease-like 2, Desmoplastic small round cell tumor, Parathyroid carcinoma, Carney-Stratakis syndrome, Hirschsprung disease, Inflammatory bowel disease 1, Crohn disease, Palmoplantar keratoderma-esophageal carcinoma syndrome, Fatal familial insomnia, Idiopathic achalasia, Pleural mesothelioma, Intestinal dysmotility syndrome, ATTRV30M amyloidosis, Autoimmune pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, Chronic beryllium disease, Autosomal dominant epidermolytic ichthyosis, Tropical pancreatitis, Amyloidosis, hereditary systemic 6, Solitary fibrous tumor, Follicular lymphoma, Glucose-galactose malabsorption, Mantle cell lymphoma.

diseases: Abnormality of bone marrow stromal cells
comment: The RPS14 gene is associated with various hematological disorders, including refractory macrocytic anemia, megakaryocyte nucleus hypolobulation, abnormality of bone marrow stromal cells, and multiple lineage myelodysplasia.
HEXB gene encodes for the alpha-N-acetyl glucosaminidase subunit of alpha-N-acetyl glucosaminidase (alpha-Galactosidase) enzyme, which is deficient in I-cell disease

SPINK5 is a gene that encodes for the serine protease inhibitor, Kazal type 5. Mutations in this gene are associated with Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita and hypernatremic dehydration, which can cause brittle scalp hair, skin blistering, and dehydration with hypernatremia.

The gene TMEM218 is associated with a range of symptoms and diseases, including obesity, central hypothyroidism, testicular enlargement, intellectual disability, facial dysmorphia, and hand anomalies.

symptoms: WAC-related facial dysmorphism-developmental delay-behavioral abnormalities syndrome
comment: RNU4ATAC gene mutations have been associated with various symptoms and diseases, including Arachnoid cysts, Familial multiple lipomatosis, Internal carotid absence, Phelan-McDermid syndrome, WAC-related facial dysmorphism-developmental delay-behavioral abnormalities syndrome, Colobomatous microphthalmia-obesity-hypogenitalism-intellectual disability syndrome

The POMK gene is associated with a range of neurological and physical symptoms, including intellectual disability, borderline syndrome, abnormal iris morphology, and fusion of the cerebellar hemispheres.

diseases: Aplasia cutis congenita over the scalp vertex
comment: The MCTP2 gene is associated with Aplasia cutis congenita, a rare skin disorder characterized by the absence of hair follicles on the scalp.

This gene provides instructions for making an enzyme called platelet-activating factor acetylhydrolase (PAF-AH). The PAF-AH enzyme breaks down a molecule called platelet-activating factor (PAF), which is involved in various physiological and pathological processes. Mutations in the PLA2G7 gene can lead to abnormal levels of PAF, resulting in platelet-activating factor acetylhydrolase deficiency, increased level of platelet-activating factor, or abnormal level of platelet-activating factor.

FOXP3 is a key regulator of immune tolerance and homeostasis in the gut. Mutations or alterations in FOXP3 expression have been implicated in Crohn's disease, leading to an imbalance in the immune response and gastrointestinal inflammation.

diseases: Abnormality of the musculature of the hand
comment: Genetic disorder that affects multiple systems in the body, including hearing, musculoskeletal, and liver function.

diseases: T-CELL IMMUNODEFICIENCY, CONGENITAL ALOPECIA, AND NAIL DYSTROPHY
comment: FOXN1 is a gene that provides instructions for making a protein called forkhead box N1. This protein plays a critical role in the development of cells, particularly those involved in the immune system.

The PRG4 gene is associated with various musculoskeletal disorders and inflammatory conditions, such as osteoarthritis of the elbow, polyarticular arthropathy, constrictive pericarditis, generalized morning stiffness, wrist swelling, flattened metacarpal heads, and flattened metatarsal heads.

ADAMTS19 is a gene that encodes a transmembrane proteoglycan involved in the regulation of extracellular matrix turnover. Mutations in this gene have been associated with thalassemia major, a severe form of anemia, and aortic root dilatation, which can lead to aortic dissection or rupture.
The DNAJB13 gene is associated with Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Return (APVR), a rare congenital heart defect where the pulmonary veins do not connect normally to the left atrium.

The AHDC1 gene is associated with a range of neurological and developmental disorders, including deafness, nystagmus, and myopia. The symptoms and abnormalities listed are commonly associated with mutations in the AHDC1 gene.
The gene SLC2A1 is linked to the symptoms, abnormalities and diseases of Otitis externa, Ear exostoses, and Fusariosis.

diseases: Abnormal circulating plasminogen activator inhibitor 1 activity
Decreased level of tissue plasminogen activator
symptoms: Abnormal circulating plasminogen activator inhibitor 1 activity
Decreased level of tissue plasminogen activator
comment: The SERPINE1 gene provides instructions for making a protein called serpin, which is involved in the regulation of blood clotting. Abnormalities in this gene have been linked to an increased risk of certain conditions.
Note: The associations provided are from the Human Phenotype Ontology (HP) and the Open Resource for Phenotypic Analysis (ORPHA).

diseases: Brain malformation-congenital heart disease-postaxial polydactyly syndrome
comment: The gene OTX2 is associated with several developmental abnormalities and diseases, including posterior pituitary hypoplasia and brain malformation-congenital heart disease-postaxial polydactyly syndrome. This suggests that OTX2 plays a critical role in embryonic development and pituitary gland formation.

diseases: Congenital plasminogen activator inhibitor type 1 deficiency
comment: The B3GALTL gene is associated with the Congenital plasminogen activator inhibitor type 1 deficiency. This condition affects the blood clotting system and can lead to bleeding disorders.
A genetic disorder associated with progressive retinal atrophy.
The gene PRX is associated with Hypertrophic nerve changes, Peripheral hypermyelination and Myelin tomacula. It affects the abnormalities of peripheral nerves.

diseases: Cardiomyopathy; Infantile liver failure syndrome 2; Short chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency; Carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase deficiency; Myopathy, myofibrillar, 4; Dyskinesia with orofacial involvement, autosomal recessive; Tibial muscular dystrophy, tardive; Hypermethioninemia with deficiency of S-adenosylhomocysteine hydrolase; Spinal muscular atrophy with congenital bone fractures 1; D-2-hydroxyglutaric aciduria 2; Ventricular tachycardia, familial; Propionic acidemia; Naxos disease; Late-onset distal myopathy, Markesbery-Griggs type; Intermediate nemaline myopathy; Myopathy, distal, 4; Muscle disorders
symptoms: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with kidney anomalies due to mitochondrial DNA mutation
Dyskinesia with orofacial involvement, autosomal recessive
Hypermethioninemia with deficiency of S-adenosylhomocysteine hydrolase
Spinal muscular atrophy with congenital bone fractures 1
comment: Multiple genes associated with cardiomyopathy, see individual OMIM entries for specific gene names and symbols.
Association with antiarrythmic agent therapy is not a disease but rather an associated treatment.

diseases: Short distal phalanx of the 3rd finger
symptoms: Congenital insensitivity to pain and temperature
comment: GNAS gene mutations are associated with multiple clinical syndromes, including Calcitonin-Related Syndrome (CRS), Fibrous Dysplasia, and Congenital Insensitivity to Pain and Temperature. These conditions are characterized by abnormalities in the development of bones, teeth, and other tissues, as well as endocrine and neurological problems.

diseases: Periosteal thickening of long tubular bones
symptoms: No specific symptoms are mentioned in the provided associations.
Possible symptoms may include general bone pain or discomfort.

diseases: Reduced branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase activity in cultured fibroblasts

comment: The NKX6-2 gene is associated with several neurological disorders. It has been linked to hypometric saccades, a condition where the saccadic eye movements are slower than normal, and abnormal exteroceptive sensations, such as feeling numbness or tingling in the extremities. The exact function of the NKX6-2 gene is not yet fully understood, but it is thought to play a role in the development and maintenance of the nervous system.

Note: RNU7-1 is a non-coding RNA, its exact function and mechanism are not fully understood. The association with Aortic aneurysm is likely due to regulatory or modulatory effects on genes involved in vascular biology.
IL12A-AS1 is a non-coding RNA gene that has been associated with various diseases, including Myositis. It's also linked to idiopathic camptocormia and focal myositis.

The SMAD4 gene is a tumor suppressor gene that plays a crucial role in the TGF-beta signaling pathway, which regulates cell growth and differentiation. Mutations in the SMAD4 gene have been implicated in Hunter-Macdonald syndrome and Lymphedema-Hypoparathyroidism syndrome.

MFSD8 is a gene that has been associated with several eye diseases and symptoms. Dyschromatopsia refers to abnormal color perception, maculopathy refers to disorders of the retina, rapidly progressive refers to the rate at which vision loss occurs, and hyperautofluorescence refers to an excessive glow of retinal tissue under certain lighting conditions.
TRPV6 gene is associated with various health issues, primarily related to the skeletal and reproductive systems.
Cryptocortal-binding protein beta-1, plays a role in the structure and function of crystallins.

diseases: Familial papillary thyroid carcinoma with renal papillary neoplasia
comment: This gene is associated with abnormal neck blood vessels and familial papillary thyroid carcinoma with renal papillary neoplasia.

diseases: Thyroid hormone resistance, generalized, autosomal dominant
comment: The THRB gene provides instructions for making a protein called thyroid hormone receptor beta.

STOX1 (Steroidogenic factor 1) is a transcription factor that plays a role in regulating blood pressure. Mutations or alterations in STOX1 expression have been associated with hypertension and elevated diastolic blood pressure.

The MYOTN gene encodes the protein myotilin, which is involved in the regulation of muscle contraction. Mutations in this gene can lead to the accumulation of abnormal myotilin protein in muscle fibers, resulting in Abnormal Z disk morphology and other symptoms associated with Myotonic Dystrophy Type 1.

diseases: Adrenal hyperplasia, congenital, due to 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 17-alpha-hydroxylase deficiency
Distal renal tubular acidosis 3, with or without sensorineural hearing loss
Nephrosis with deafness and urinary tract and digital malformations
comment: No specific gene is mentioned in the provided associations. The conditions listed are associated with X-linked dominant inheritance but do not specify a particular gene.
Association with Aortic Valve Disease 2 not found in literature.

diseases: Autosomal recessive cerebellar ataxia due to STUB1 deficiency
Progressive encephalopathy with leukodystrophy due to DECR deficiency
Early-onset epileptic encephalopathy and intellectual disability due to GRIN2A mutation
comment: Note: GM2 gangliosidosis is a lysosomal storage disease, whereas the other conditions seem to be more directly related to HCN1 mutations.
SLRP (Slipped Capital Ligament Raphe Protein) gene is linked to Spondylolysis and Spondylosis, cervical.
TCOF1 gene mutation is associated with certain developmental and congenital disorders.

SLC25A1 is a gene that encodes for an enzyme called succinate:quinone oxidoreductase, which plays a crucial role in the electron transport chain. Mutations in this gene have been associated with Coenzyme Q10 Deficiency.

ATL1 is a gene that encodes a transmembrane protein involved in the transport of ions across cell membranes. Mutations in this gene have been associated with various neurodegenerative diseases, including Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), Hereditary spastic paraplegia, and Familial amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

The RTL1 gene is associated with MODY, a form of diabetes that typically develops during adolescence or early adulthood. It is characterized by an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern and can lead to mild to severe hyperglycemia.
Genetic association study suggests PRSS56 gene is linked to various eye abnormalities and diseases.
Also known as Keratin 10, this gene provides instructions for making a protein called keratin 10. Mutations in the KRT10 gene have been associated with certain skin conditions.
The MMP13 gene is associated with Spondyloepimetaphyseal dysplasia, Missouri type and Spondylometaphyseal dysplasia, A4 type. It also causes flared and irregular rib ends.

TRAF7 is a gene that has been associated with trigeminal neuralgia, pituitary apoplexy and paroxysmal hemicrania. The exact mechanism of how TRAF7 contributes to these conditions is not fully understood.

solute carrier family 5 (transporter member 1) gene. The SLC5A1 gene provides instructions for making a protein called solute carrier 5 (ASC), which plays a critical role in the transport of certain substances across cell membranes.

The GDF6 gene is associated with neck pain and spastic paraplegia 25, an autosomal recessive disorder. It may also be linked to myxopapillary ependymoma, a rare type of brain tumor.

comment: CCM2 gene mutations are associated with a range of vascular skin abnormalities and diseases, including Sneddon syndrome, Aspartylglucosaminuria, Familial cerebral cavernous malformation, and Segmental progressive overgrowth syndrome with fibroadipose hyperplasia.

Other genes linked to these symptoms and diseases include: 15q11.2 deletion syndrome (maternal 15q11q13 deletion) and Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease. P4HTM is not a gene but rather a provisional HP reference.

ANKRD55 is a gene associated with several rheumatic diseases, including rheumatoid arthritis, oligoarthritis, and osteoarthritis. It is also linked to enthesitis, iridocyclitis, and synovitis, which are conditions that affect the joints and surrounding tissues.

diseases: Corneal dystrophy of bowman layer, type II
comment: The ZFHX2 gene is a collagen helix homolog gene that plays a role in the structure and function of corneal epithelium. Mutations in this gene have been associated with certain types of corneal dystrophies, such as Corneal dystrophy of bowman layer, type II and Epithelial recurrent erosion dystrophy.
Note: Nemaline myopathy can have multiple associated genes. The association between RNU4ATAC and Amish nemaline myopathy is specific to the Amish population.
The FBN1 gene is associated with Marfan syndrome, a genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissue.
Buerger disease is a rare disorder characterized by inflammation of the blood vessels in the arms and legs, leading to pain, numbness, and potentially life-threatening complications.

The NEU1 gene is associated with abnormalities in tissue neuraminidase activity, increased urinary O-linked sialopeptides, aplasia/hypoplasia of the fovea, and urinary excretion of sialylated oligosaccharides.

The gene associated with these associations is the Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone Receptor (TSHR) gene. This gene provides instructions for making a protein called the TSH receptor, which plays a critical role in regulating thyroid function.

The BHLHA9 gene provides instructions for making a protein called bHLHa (basic helix-loop-helix alpha A). This protein is involved in the development of certain tissues and organs during embryonic development. Mutations in the BHLHA9 gene are associated with an overfolded helix structure, which can lead to various developmental abnormalities and diseases.

The KCNK18 gene provides instructions for making a protein called potassium two-pore channel, subfamily K (KvLQT1). Mutations in this gene have been associated with an increased risk of developing migraine with or without aura.
The ARX gene provides instructions for making a protein called aristaless homolog.
KCNJ18 gene mutations lead to exercise-induced muscle fatigue and adenosine monophosphate deaminase deficiency.

-- Chd7 is a gene that encodes a protein involved in chromatin remodeling and transcription regulation. Mutations in CHD7 have been associated with Becker nevus syndrome, which is characterized by skin lesions, brain abnormalities, and other developmental disorders. Abnormal tibia morphology has also been linked to mutations in the CHD7 gene.
YY1 gene mutations have been associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) and other disorders.

Note: MYMX gene is associated with cerebral calcification and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus with intracranial calcification. Also, there's a connection to teratoma of the pineal gland, although that might be a secondary association.
FXN gene mutation is linked to the symptoms, abnormalities and diseases.

SLC9A3 gene is linked to gastrointestinal ulcer and various other symptoms and abnormalities, including elevated fecal sodium, abnormal fecal osmolality, reduced fecal osmolality, abnormal fecal pH, elevated fecal pH, elevated stool chloride content and abnormal blood sodium concentration.
Tumor Necrosis Factor Receptor Superfamily Member 11A (TNFRSF11A), also known as RANK, is a gene that plays a critical role in regulating bone resorption and remodeling.

Multiple OMIM numbers indicate that different genes may be associated with the same disease. OMIM numbers 218350 and 612491 are listed together under HP:Subarachnoid hemorrhage, suggesting a possible genetic link between CD109 and subarachnoid hemorrhage.
The gene associated with the symptoms, abnormalities and diseases is SERPINA12. This gene is linked to Hyperkeratosis with erythema and Diffuse palmoplantar hyperkeratosis.
The TTBK2 gene is linked to Spinocerebellar ataxia 11 and Spinocerebellar ataxia type 11, which is characterized by jerky ocular pursuit movements among other symptoms.
The SCGB3A2 gene is associated with airway hyperresponsiveness, a key feature of asthma.
The AXIN2 gene is linked to the development of fundic gland polyposis and abnormal odontoid tissue morphology.

diseases: Genetic anticipation with paternal anticipation bias
comment: The ATXN7 gene is associated with Supranuclear Ophthalmoplegia, a condition characterized by abnormal movements of the eyes. Additionally, it has been linked to genetic anticipation and paternal anticipation bias, which refer to the phenomenon where the onset of symptoms tends to occur earlier in males than females.

symptoms: Progeroid features such as balding, wrinkled skin
comment: The GDF11 gene is associated with idiopathic scoliosis and progeroid syndrome. Mutations in this gene have been linked to these conditions, which are characterized by abnormal spine curvature, short stature, and other symptoms.

The MYO1H gene is associated with Ganglioneuroblastoma, a rare type of cancer that affects the nervous system. It is also linked to Congenital central hypoventilation syndrome and Hirschsprung disease-ganglioneuroblastoma syndrome.

SMAD9 is a gene that plays a crucial role in the TGF- signaling pathway, which regulates various cellular processes including growth, differentiation, and apoptosis. Mutations or alterations in this gene have been linked to several cardiovascular diseases and abnormalities.

diseases: Coarctation of the descending aortic arch
symptoms: Coarctation of the descending aortic arch
comment: The gene ALG3 is linked to several genetic disorders, including abnormal uvula morphology and coarctation of the descending aortic arch.
CLDN19 is a gene that encodes for a protein involved in the functioning of tight junctions. Mutations in this gene have been linked to various disorders, including those listed above.

All the mentioned syndromes have a common gene - ZIC2. The exact role of this gene in human health is still not well understood, but it has been associated with various developmental disorders and abnormalities.
ALG11 gene mutations cause a range of symptoms including vision problems, intellectual disability, and movement disorders.
Association with KANSL1 may imply a genetic component to the condition.

gene: Multiple genes are associated with various skin conditions listed in OMIM entries. Some of the genes mentioned include: PERCC1 (pericentrin-1), COL4A3/4/5/6 (types of collagen), ABCB11, CYP27B1 (vitamin D metabolism), FBN1 (fibrillin-1), SMAD2, SMAD3, SMAD4, PLOP1, ARNT2, VPS45, ALOX12-1, NOS3, GNAQ, COL5A1
diseases: Noduli cutanei, multiple, with urinary tract abnormalities
Metaphyseal modeling abnormality, skin lesions, and spastic paraplegia
Keratosis palmaris et plantaris with clinodactyly
comment: The OMIM (Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man) database is a comprehensive collection of genetic disorder information. The gene(s) associated with each disease listed above may be complex and involve multiple genes. This list provides a starting point for research, but it's essential to consult additional sources and experts for more specific information.

symptoms: Abnormalities in Neuroendocrine system of appendix
comment: SPRED1 gene is associated with Ovarian neoplasm and Abnormalities in Neuroendocrine system of appendix.

RSPO2 is a gene that plays a crucial role in the development of the pancreas, lungs, and other organs. Mutations in this gene have been linked to several congenital disorders, including aplasia/hypoplasia of the lungs, prune belly syndrome, and achondrogenesis type 1A.
This information suggests that TICAM1 is a gene associated with reduced consciousness and pineoblastoma.
The gene PAH is linked to Tyrosinemia Type I, a genetic disorder that affects the liver and can cause acute hepatic failure.
The MYMX gene provides instructions for making a protein called myoxin A, which is involved in the development and maintenance of bones.

EFEMP2 gene is associated with various vascular and developmental abnormalities, including pulmonary artery aneurysm, vascular tortuosity, hypoplasia of the diaphragm, arterial tortuosity, urethral diverticulum, small bowel diverticula, and multiple bladder diverticula.

symptoms: Increased urine proteinogenic amino acid derivative level
comment: The HTRT1 gene is responsible for encoding the histidase enzyme, which plays a crucial role in breaking down the amino acid histidine. Mutations or deficiencies in this enzyme lead to histidinemia and histidinuria, two conditions characterized by elevated levels of histidine and its metabolites in the urine.
ARMC12 gene is linked to the symptoms and diseases such as Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome and Abnormal circulating follicle-stimulating hormone concentration.

The SETDB1 gene has been associated with Impairment in personality functioning and Frontotemporal dementia. Manganese poisoning is also linked to this gene as it can lead to neurodegenerative diseases.

diseases: Desquamation of skin soon after birth
Recurrent upper and lower respiratory tract infections
comment: DCLRE1C gene is associated with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) disorder.
Calcium channel gene mutations cause hypocalcemia which in turn causes the above mentioned signs and symptoms

The CLOCK gene is involved in regulating circadian rhythms. Variations in this gene have been associated with early chronotype and advance sleep phase syndrome, which are characterized by abnormal sleep-wake cycles and disrupted circadian rhythms.
TRAPPC14 gene mutations have been associated with various types of lipomas and other fatty tissue neoplasms, particularly in the spine.
This association suggests that mutations in the SRPX2 gene may be linked to unilateral focal polymicrogyria and parietal focal spikes, which is a type of abnormal brain activity.

diseases: Cardiac conduction defects sudden cardiac death
Progressive familial heart block, type II
comment: BMPR1A gene mutations are associated with several conditions that affect the cardiovascular system.

diseases: Neurodevelopmental disorder with central and peripheral motor dysfunction

comment: HGSNAT gene mutations are associated with a range of symptoms and diseases, including visual impairment, musculoskeletal abnormalities, and various eye and bone disorders.

diseases: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
Abnormality of the epiphyses of the 2nd finger

Aplasia of the proximal phalanx of the 2nd finger

Aplasia involving bones of the extremities

Aplasia of the phalanges of the toes
comment: BMPR1B gene mutation is associated with various skeletal abnormalities, including aplastic and hypoplastic changes in bones of the upper and lower limbs.
CMPK2 is a gene associated with various neurological disorders. The symptoms and diseases listed are conditions that have been linked to mutations or variations in the CMPK2 gene.
ZNFX1 gene is linked to a group of rare genetic disorders that cause autoimmunity and immune dysfunction, leading to various symptoms and diseases listed above.

diseases: Delayed ability to walk with support
Abnormality of peripheral nervous system electrophysiology
symptoms: Numbness or tingling in hands and feet
comment: ITPR1 gene is a receptor gene involved in the regulation of cell growth, differentiation, and migration. Mutations in this gene have been associated with various neurological disorders, including the listed conditions.

diseases: Proteinuria, low molecular weight, with hypercalciuric nephrocalcinosis
comment: PKD1 gene mutations are associated with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) but some of the above-mentioned symptoms may also be linked to other genes as well.

symptoms: abnormalities in the cerebellum leading to spinocerebellar ataxia 8 (SCA8)
comment: The PNPLA6 gene is associated with both Spinocerebellar atrophy 8 (SCA8) and abnormal antitragus morphology.

The SLC34A3 gene is involved in the regulation of calcium reabsorption in the kidneys. Mutations in this gene have been associated with Vitamin D-dependent rickets type 2B, a rare genetic disorder characterized by defective mineralization of bones.

TRAPPC11 gene is linked to Alacrima syndrome which is characterized by various symptoms and diseases including Neuropathy, Helix syndrome, Kilquist syndrome, Achalasia-Addisonianism-Alacrima syndrome, Glucocorticoid deficiency 2 and Mental retardation, X-linked, syndromic 17.
The NOTCH2 gene is associated with various neurological disorders, including NOTCH2 NLC, Leber optic atrophy, Mitochondrial Leigh syndrome, and Pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration.
This gene is associated with Factor XIII subunit A deficiency, a disorder that affects the blood's ability to clot. The symptoms of this condition include abnormal onset of bleeding.
The OPN1LW gene is associated with color vision deficiency, specifically protanopia (red-blindness) and partial color vision.

MTMR14 is a gene that encodes for myotrophin, a protein involved in muscle function. Mutations in this gene are associated with Myotonic Dystrophy type 1, a genetic disorder characterized by muscle stiffness and wasting.

diseases: White lesion of the oral mucosa
comment: The gene DCLRE1B is associated with both Pancolitis and White lesion of the oral mucosa. It plays a crucial role in the development of these conditions by affecting the immune system's response to inflammation.

diseases: Methylmalonic acidemia with homocystinuria, type cblD
comment: The CLN12 gene is associated with Methylmalonic acidemia with homocystinuria, type cblD and Thyroid hypoplasia. The symptoms of Fatigue are common to both diseases.
Antithrombin (ANT) -related gene associated with various conditions

The LYST gene provides instructions for making a protein called lysosomal trafficking regulator. This protein plays a critical role in the functioning of certain organelles within cells, including the dense granules found in neutrophils.

The DICER1 gene is linked to a range of cancer-related symptoms and diseases, including pleuropulmonary blastoma and rhabdomyosarcoma. The exact function of the DICER1 gene is unclear, but it plays a crucial role in regulating gene expression and RNA processing.

The NEUROG1 gene is associated with various congenital disorders, particularly those affecting the auditory and visual systems. It encodes a transcription factor that plays a crucial role in neural crest development.

The LMNA gene provides instructions for making two proteins called lamin A and lamin C. Mutations in the LMNA gene are associated with a range of diseases, including Dermatoleukodystrophy and Progeroid facial appearance.

Distal deletion 12q syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the SUMF1 gene, which codes for the sumolytic enzyme SUMF1. This enzyme plays a crucial role in the regulation of RNA processing and has been implicated in various developmental abnormalities, including Broad hallux.

The Bmp4 gene plays a crucial role in embryonic development, particularly in the formation of abdominal organs. Mutations or alterations in this gene have been linked to Abdominal organ duplication and Disorganization.
PTRH2 gene mutations are associated with a range of physical abnormalities and diseases.
The RIPK4 gene is associated with Commissural lip pits, a condition characterized by small, fluid-filled sacs on the surface of the brain.
A gene mutation in SDHAF1 has been associated with abnormal left ventricular function.
ANO10 gene is linked to various symptoms and diseases including tortuosity of conjunctival vessels.

OSPA (OspA) gene is associated with Japanese encephalitis, a disease caused by the flavivirus. The OspA protein is found on the surface of the virus and plays a crucial role in its attachment to host cells. Pulmonary edema is a symptom that can occur in severe cases of Japanese encephalitis.

The gene CPT1C is associated with Spastic Paraplegia 20, a rare genetic disorder. It affects the nervous system and causes symptoms such as urinary urgency, which is also mentioned in another association.
Genetic disorder
These conditions are associated with mutations in the PKHD1 gene.

TNFRSF1A is a gene that encodes for the tumor necrosis factor receptor superfamily member 1A protein, also known as TNF receptor 1. It plays a crucial role in immune system function and has been linked to several diseases and conditions, including fasciitis, abnormal fascia morphology, abnormal knee physiology, and knee joint hypermobility.

MMP2 is a gene that encodes for matrix metalloproteinase-2, an enzyme involved in the degradation of the extracellular matrix. Mutations or alterations in this gene have been linked to various abnormalities and diseases, including those listed above.

diseases: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis and neurodevelopmental syndrome
comment: Associated with SMAD4 gene mutation.
Mutations in the FGB gene lead to Kniest dyschondrosteosis, a rare genetic disorder characterized by abnormalities in bone growth and development.

The BMPR1A gene is a receptor for the bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs) and plays a crucial role in embryonic development. Mutations in this gene have been associated with Abnormal liver lobulation and Mosaic trisomy 9 syndrome.
The CELSR1 gene provides instructions for making a protein called cadherin-related static linkage regulator 1, which is involved in the development of the lymphatic system.

diseases: Deviation of the hand or of fingers of the hand
Aplasia of the phalanges of the hand
symptoms: Deviation or displacement of the hand/fingers
comment: LMBR1 gene associated with a range of limb abnormalities, including duplication, aplasia, and deformities. The effects can vary greatly from person to person.
GDF6 gene mutation is linked to Abnormal limb bone morphology and Hypotrichosis with juvenile macular degeneration.
The H19 gene is involved in asymmetric growth.
SDHD gene is also associated with other diseases and conditions, including Paraganglioma and Pheochromocytoma.
JPHN1 gene mutation associated with OCLN syndrome. OCLN stands for Olivopontocerebellar atrophy, a rare genetic disorder that affects the cerebellum and brainstem.

Muscular dystrophy, congenital, merosin deficient or partially deficient
comment: NOTCH2NLC not found in OMIM database
The gene LMOD2 is linked to thromboembolic stroke, familial atrial fibrillation and other conditions. The exact relationship between the gene and the diseases is not fully understood.

TMEM218 is associated with Hypothyroidism, intellectual disability-facial dysmorphism-hand anomalies syndrome and Obesity. The symptoms of the diseases are Testicular enlargement, Intellectual disability,facial dysmorphism and Hand anomalies.

The NF1 gene is responsible for the symptoms, abnormalities, and diseases associated with this association. Cafe-au-lait spots are a common feature of Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), which is caused by mutations in the NF1 gene.

diseases: Intrinsic factor and R binder deficiency
comment: combined congenital deficiency
The gene DCD is associated with Fasting hypoglycemia, Dicarboxylicamino aciduria and Glycogen storage disease 0.

The KANSL1 gene is associated with speech apraxia, Rolandic epilepsy, and intellectual disability. Speech apraxia is a disorder of voluntary movement that affects the ability to form words, while Rolandic epilepsy is a type of seizure disorder that affects children. Intellectual disability refers to significant limitations in both intellectual functioning and adaptive behavior.

comment: Also known as Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, this gene mutation can lead to emphysema, liver disease and sometimes Panniculitis.

The AMELogenesis imperfecta gene provides instructions for making a protein called amelogenin, which is important in the formation of tooth enamel. Mutations in the AMBN gene can lead to Amelogenesis imperfecta, a condition characterized by defective tooth enamel development.
The gene STOX1 is associated with polygenic inheritance of certain diseases and abnormalities, including atrial fibrillation, hydrops fetalis, and follicular lymphoma.
Mutations in PAX7 have been associated with familial congenital mammary dysplasia, which can also cause supernumerary nipples.

diseases: Albinism, ocular, with late-onset sensorineural deafness

comment: The HPRT1 gene is associated with Podagra (inflammation of the big toe joint) and Gout (a type of arthritis characterized by sudden, severe joint pain).

The genetic basis of these conditions involves mutations in genes that encode proteins involved in androgen signaling, such as the androgen receptor (AR), 3-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase (HSD3B2), and 17-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase type 3 (17-HSD3).
The SRY gene is a crucial gene in sex determination and is linked to unilateral or bilateral cryptorchidism.
ABCC8 gene mutation is associated with Progressive Familial Intrahepatic Cholestasis type 3, a rare genetic disorder that affects the liver and causes abnormal fat digestion.

diseases: Chronic nonbacterial osteomyelitis/Chronic recurrent multifocal osteomyelitis
comment: Association with Palmoplantar pustulosis and Chronic nonbacterial osteomyelitis/Chronic recurrent multifocal osteomyelitis
Fibrillin-1 (FN1) gene mutation is associated with various disorders, including congenital contractural arachnodactyly, spondylodysplastic short-limbed syndrome, and supravalvular aortic stenosis.

The TOE1 gene is associated with ovotesticular difference of sex development and abnormal scrotal rugation. Ovotesticular difference of sex development refers to a rare condition where an individual has both ovarian and testicular tissue, leading to ambiguity in their sex assignment. Abnormal scrotal rugation may involve irregularities or abnormalities in the texture or appearance of the scrotum.

The condition linked to the ORPHA:Congenital bilateral absence of vas deferens association is more likely due to a different gene (BRCA2 or BMP1).

The SLX4 gene provides instructions for making a protein that is involved in maintaining the integrity of DNA during replication. Mutations in this gene have been linked to aplasia/hypoplasia of fingers.

Anomalous origin of coronary artery from the pulmonary artery

comment: HIBCH stands for Hydroxymethylbilane Hydratase/Coenzyme A lyase, which is a gene that encodes an enzyme involved in the metabolism of certain amino acids. The association suggests that mutations or alterations in this gene may lead to abnormalities in mitochondrial metabolism and reduced activity of 3-hydroxyisobutyryl-CoA hydrolase.

symptoms: Abnormal CSF glutamine family amino acid concentration
comment: The ASL gene mutation is responsible for AASS, a rare genetic disorder. The mutations affect the aspartoacylase enzyme, leading to an accumulation of glutamine and other related amino acids in the body.

comment: This gene is associated with abnormal glycosylation in humans.
The TREM2 gene is associated with an increased risk of Alzheimer's disease and other neurodegenerative disorders.

The KCNNT1 gene is associated with intellectual developmental disorders and periventricular nodular heterotopia, characterized by reduced cerebral white matter volume.

comment: The gene C1S is associated with hereditary angioedema (HAE), which can also cause gingival fragility and pretibial hyperpigmentation.

The CCR2 gene is associated with an increased risk of developing certain conditions, particularly in newborns. It plays a crucial role in the development and function of the lungs.
GDF6 is a gene associated with abnormal rib morphology and Trisomy 18 syndrome.

symptoms: Abnormal levels of phosphohydroxylysine in urine
comment: The gene PSAP (phosphoserine aminopeptidase) is responsible for the condition Phosphohydroxylysinuria, which affects the body's ability to break down phosphohydroxylysine. The elevated levels of this amino acid in the urine are a hallmark of the disease.

comment: CAVIN1 is a gene that encodes for a protein involved in the regulation of skeletal muscle function, particularly in relation to neuromuscular transmission. Mutations in this gene have been associated with myotonia with skeletal abnormalities and mental retardation, a rare genetic disorder characterized by muscle stiffness, intellectual disability, and other developmental delays.
SLC26A1 gene is also associated with other diseases. It's a sulfate transport protein and mutations in this gene can lead to various abnormalities.

The COL7A1 gene is responsible for producing a protein called collagen VII, which is essential for the integrity and strength of skin. Mutations in this gene can lead to premature skin wrinkling and elastoderma.
the gene RNU7-1 is associated with Fetal akinesia syndrome and Arrhinencephaly, which are X-linked conditions
APP-related

These symptoms are often associated with a condition known as CFAP418-related disease or CFAP418 syndrome.
HP gene is associated with elevated levels of hypoxanthine, leading to various symptoms and diseases such as hyperuricemia, xanthinuria, and gout.
The GREB1 gene is associated with Abnormal semicircular canal morphology and Deafness. The symptoms include autosomal recessive inheritance.
PSCK9 is a gene that encodes for the low-density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 1 (LRP1). It plays a critical role in lipid metabolism and has been linked to hypercholesterolemia.

comment: CASK gene mutation is associated with Fava bean-induced hemolytic anemia, Heinz bodies and decreased glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase level in blood.
Dispensable insulin-like peptide 1 gene. Mutations in this gene have been associated with familial advanced sleep phase syndrome.
RTL1 is associated with Meier-Gorlin syndrome which includes Hypoplasia of the maxilla.

comment: CCNQ gene is linked to the symptoms, abnormalities and diseases including Hypoplasia of the bladder, SERKAL syndrome, and 46,XX sex reversal with dysgenesis of kidneys, adrenals, and lungs.

symptoms: prolonged bleeding after injury or surgery
comment: Factor XIII subunit B is a gene that provides instructions for making a protein called fibrin stabilizing factor XIII subunit B. This protein is involved in the blood clotting process.

Achondroplasia-related MYH3 gene mutations leading to fibrous dysplasia, syndactyly and other limb abnormalities. Mutations in this gene have also been associated with spondylometaphyseal dysplasia (SMD), which may cause fused vertebrae and multiple pterygia, a condition characterized by the presence of multiple small wing-like projections on the upper surface of the nose and sometimes on the eyelids.
Gene mutation leading to hypomature dental enamel in individuals with Amelogenesis imperfecta, a rare genetic disorder.

comment: IKZF5 gene mutations have been associated with several hematological abnormalities and diseases, including immunodeficiency, disseminated intravascular coagulation, impaired ristocetin-induced platelet aggregation, reduced alpha granules, and reduced dense granules in platelets.

The ADAMTSL1 gene is associated with Rieger anomaly and Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome, type 1. Rieger anomaly is a rare congenital eye anomaly characterized by iris heterochromia and corneal thinning, while Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome is a group of disorders that affect the development of the anterior segment of the eye.
a small nuclear RNA (snoRNA) gene that is involved in regulating gene expression.

The UPB1 gene encodes the enzyme beta-ureidopropionase, which is involved in the degradation of certain amino acids. Mutations in this gene have been associated with bladder exstrophy, a rare congenital anomaly of the urinary system.

The COL3A1 gene is a critical component in the production of type III collagen, which plays a crucial role in the development and maintenance of connective tissue. Mutations or abnormalities in this gene have been linked to various conditions, including hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, abdominal wall defects, and labial hypertrophy.
The PAF1K gene provides instructions for making a protein that is involved in the maintenance of myelin, the fatty substance that surrounds and protects nerve fibers.

NOTCH2 gene is associated with Distal lower limb amyotrophy, Spinal muscular atrophy-Dandy-Walker malformation-cataracts syndrome and Foix-Alajouanine syndrome. Amyotrophy refers to muscle wasting or shrinkage, typically in the distal (far) parts of the limbs.

The COL7A1 gene is involved in the production of collagen VII, a protein that provides structure and strength to skin, hair, and nails. Mutations in this gene can lead to abnormalities in these tissues, resulting in conditions such as Ledderhose disease and Lipodystrophy type 2 (LIPN).
This gene is associated with Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia-brachydactyly-speech disorder syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of bones and joints.
The ANKRD55 gene is associated with synovial lining hyperplasia and Camptodactyly-Arthropathy-Coxa vara-pericarditis syndrome, a rare genetic disorder.

diseases: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin
symptoms: Excessive sweating on palms and soles
comment: R-spondin 1 gene mutations have been linked to various congenital abnormalities, cancers, and other diseases.

NRAS gene is a mutation-associated gene that plays a critical role in the regulation of cell growth, differentiation, and survival. Mutations in the NRAS gene have been linked to various diseases, including melanoma, neuroblastoma, and other cancers.
Abnormal number of dense granules in platelets is also associated with HPS3
The gene F12 encodes for Factor XII, a protein involved in blood clotting. Deficiency of this protein can lead to prolonged whole-blood clotting time.

symptoms: Maternal uniparental disomy of chromosome 4 syndrome
Lipodystrophy due to peptidic growth factors deficiency

PLA2R gene mutations are associated with Pulmonary Venous Hypertension (PVH), Myocardial Infarction, and Diffuse Alveolar Hemorrhage. The symptoms include hemoptysis, cough, shortness of breath, and cardiac arrhythmias.
The TNNI3K gene is not directly linked to the symptoms, abnormalities and diseases. The correct gene associated with these conditions is JPHNA1.
The gene MMO1 is associated with elevated levels of certain types of steroids in the blood, which can lead to various health problems.

symptoms: Congenital stationary night blindness with normal fundus
Congenital stationary night blindness with abnormal fundus
comment: GPR179 is a G protein-coupled receptor that has been associated with various eye disorders, including congenital stationary night blindness and high myopia.

diseases: Abnormal spatial orientation of the cardiac segments
symptoms: Abnormal spatial orientation of the cardiac segments
comment: PKD1L1 gene mutations are associated with certain congenital heart defects and anomalies.

The H19 gene is a non-coding gene, but it has been implicated in various congenital abnormalities and diseases. In this case, it is associated with upper limb asymmetry and other conditions such as isolated humero-radio-ulnar synostosis and diaphragmatic defect-limb deficiency-skull defect syndrome.
CCM2 is a gene associated with cerebral cavitary malformations, including those mentioned in the provided associations.
Genetic mutations in the TWIST2 gene may be associated with the development of these disorders, characterized by various abnormalities and symptoms including sparse or absent eyelashes.

The gene PTPN11 encodes a protein tyrosine phosphatase that is involved in cell signaling pathways. Mutations in this gene are responsible for Hutchinson-gilford Progeria Syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by premature aging and various physical abnormalities.
STAB1 gene is associated with the regulation of hepcidin, which plays a crucial role in iron metabolism. Abnormal levels of hepcidin can lead to various iron-related disorders.

The DRD4 gene has been linked to an increased risk of developing borderline personality disorder, as well as other mental health conditions. Variants of this gene have been associated with abnormalities in personality functioning and social cognition.

diseases: Microcephaly with epilepsy and diabetes syndrome
comment: PHCBA1 gene mutations can lead to various physical, developmental, and cognitive abnormalities. Note: The disease Microcephaly 22 is OMIM#616461 which can be associated with other genes also.

gene: ESAM (Endothelin-1 Receptor Stimulating And Muscarinic receptor stimulating related protein)

comment: The gene ESAM (Endothelin-1 Receptor Stimulating And Muscarinic receptor stimulating related protein) is a protein-coding gene that encodes a protein involved in the regulation of endothelin and muscarinic receptors.
The WDR35 gene is associated with various genetic disorders. The specific symptoms and diseases linked to this gene include fused teeth and a cloverleaf skull, among others.

symptoms: Decreased circulating terminal complement component concentration
comment: The gene C5 is associated with the symptoms and diseases mentioned above. The exact relationship between the gene and the conditions is not explicitly stated in the provided information.

GATA3 protein is a transcription factor that plays a crucial role in the development of the nervous system. Mutations in the GATM gene can lead to impaired GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) synthesis, resulting in GABA-transaminase deficiency.

ZNF699 is a transcription factor that has been implicated in the regulation of podocyte function and survival. Mutations in ZNF699 have been associated with chronic kidney disease, suggesting a potential role for this gene in the development or progression of kidney disease.
The IL12A-AS1 gene has been associated with gait disturbance, a condition that affects the way a person walks.
Gene associated with pregnancy complications, including stillbirth and hydatidiform mole. A history of past obstetric history may also be related to this gene.
Note: The gene JMJD1C is also associated with giant cell arteritis.
PNPLA8 is associated with Mitochondrial myopathy with lactic acidosis, and also decreased CSF 5-methyltetrahydrofolate concentration. The gene PNPLA8 is located on chromosome 14q32.2.

HCN1 is a gene that codes for a potassium channel subunit involved in the regulation of neuronal excitability. Mutations in HCN1 have been linked to atypical absence status epilepticus and early infantile epileptic encephalopathy, characterized by seizures, developmental delays, and intellectual disability.
The HMCN1 gene is associated with Macular drusen and Acute zonal occult outer retinopathy.

comment: - The SLC35C1 gene is associated with Congenital disorder of glycosylation, type IIc and abnormal serum insulin-like growth factor 1 levels.

diseases: Reduced C27 3beta-HSD activity in cultured fibroblasts
comment: The HSD3B7 gene is associated with reduced activity of the enzyme 3-beta-hydroxy Delta-5-steroid dehydrogenase, which plays a crucial role in cholesterol metabolism. This reduction in activity has been linked to neonatal cholestatic liver disease and giant cell hepatitis.

ATXN8 is a gene that encodes a protein involved in the regulation of RNA stability. Mutations in this gene are associated with several neurodegenerative disorders, including spinocerebellar ataxia type 8, Tay-Sachs disease, and hyperekplexia 1. The symptoms and abnormalities associated with these diseases include progressive ataxia, muscle stiffness, seizures, and cognitive impairment.
Typified by somatic mosaicism
The gene ITGB4 is associated with macular hypopigmentation and dyschromatosis symmetrica hereditaria.

The SFTPA2 gene provides instructions for making a protein that is involved in the production of folate (vitamin B9). Mutations in this gene can lead to a deficiency in folate, which is necessary for the proper functioning of many bodily processes. The symptoms associated with mutations in SFTPA2 include clubbing of fingers and pseudoaminopterin syndrome.

USP9X gene mutation associated with multiple congenital abnormalities, including breast hypoplasia, finger curvature, skin discoloration, biliary system issues, periodontal abnormalities, low APGAR scores, and hyperextensible thumbs.
The gene RNU4ATAC is linked to Hypotaurinemic retinal degeneration and cardiomyopathy. It may also be associated with peripheral visual field loss.

diseases: Autosomal recessive complex spastic paraplegia due to Kennedy pathway dysfunction
comment: Mutations in the ATP7A gene are associated with these conditions. The gene is involved in copper transport and homeostasis.

diseases: Abnormal fetal central nervous system morphology
comment: Diaphantine Hyperparasite Sensitivity Protein 1 (HPS1) is a protein that in humans is encoded by the HPS1 gene. Mutations in this gene have been associated with abnormally developed central nervous systems and multiple forms of intracranial hemorrhage in fetuses.

symptoms: increased level of L-pyroglutamic acid in urine
comment: The OPLAH gene is associated with pyroglutamic aciduria, a rare genetic disorder characterized by an increased level of L-pyroglutamic acid in the urine and reduced circulating 5-oxoprolinase activity.
HMGCR gene mutations are associated with certain genetic disorders that affect the heart and muscles.

diseases: Epileptic encephalopathy, early infantile, 25, with amelogenesis imperfecta
symptoms: Global developmental delay-neuro-ophthalmological abnormalities-seizures-intellectual disability syndrome
comment: The gene ABCB4 is associated with several disorders that involve symptoms such as delayed myelination, global developmental delay, and seizures. It also plays a role in energy metabolism and has been linked to various diseases, including combined oxidative phosphorylation deficiency and pontocerebellar hypoplasia.

diseases: Abnormality of the shoulder girdle musculature
symptoms: abnormality of the shoulder girdle musculature
comment: PNPLA2 gene is associated with Abnormality of the shoulder girdle musculature.

diseases: Abnormal pituitary glycoprotein hormone alpha subunit level
Increased pituitary glycoprotein hormone alpha subunit level
comment: TSHB gene encodes for the thyroid-stimulating hormone beta subunit, and mutations in this gene can lead to abnormal production of TSH, resulting in symptoms such as hyperthyroidism, thyroid eye disease, and other related conditions.

symptoms: WAC-related facial dysmorphism-developmental delay-behavioral abnormalities syndrome

comment: OPN1MW is a gene associated with Deuteranomaly and Colorblindness. It codes for the OPN1MW protein, which plays a crucial role in color vision.
ASPCR1 is a tumor suppressor gene, mutations in which are associated with alveolar soft part sarcoma.

Abnormality of skeletal muscle fiber size
symptoms: SMARCB1 is a tumor suppressor gene that plays a crucial role in regulating cell growth and division.
Mutations in SMARCB1 have been associated with an increased risk of various cancers, including lymphoma and rhabdomyosarcoma.
comment: The SMARCB1 gene is a critical component of the SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complex. It encodes for a protein that interacts with other proteins to regulate gene expression and maintain genome stability.
The ACTA1 gene is associated with IgG4-related disease, which can cause abnormalities in blood vessel morphology, including the common carotid artery.
The GATC gene is associated with various conditions. In this case, it's linked to nonimmune hydrops fetalis and decreased circulating cortisol levels.
Associated with various eye abnormalities and diseases.
