comment: TAF8 gene is associated with various neurological disorders and developmental abnormalities.
The WDR73 gene is associated with various neurological disorders, including progressive extrapyramidal movement disorders and abnormalities in hand movements.
The ATXN8 gene is responsible for the symptoms, abnormalities, and diseases associated with Spinocerebellar ataxia type 5.
The gene CEP85L is associated with motor stereotypy and other disorders.
Imprinted gene. Autosomal dominant inheritance.
TMEM240 gene associated with Hypermetric saccades, Microsaccadic pursuit, Intermittent microsaccadic pursuits and Akinesia.

Abnormal naive CD4-positive T cell proportion

involved in carnitine transport

Note: OCSTM is an acronym for Osteocalcin Stimulating Transmembrane Protein. However, based on the provided associations, it appears that SLC34A3 is also linked to increased circulating osteocalcin levels. Therefore, further research is necessary to determine if there is a specific gene associated with all the mentioned conditions.

The DNAJB13 gene is associated with an abnormal connection of the pulmonary veins, which can lead to hydrocephaly-low insertion umbilicus syndrome, a rare congenital disorder characterized by an abnormally low-lying umbilicus and sometimes hydrocephalus (fluid accumulation in the brain).

diseases: Paradoxical Splitting of the Second Heart Sound
comment: KCNJ2 gene mutations are associated with Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Cardiomyopathy (ARVC), which can also lead to automatic atrachycardia, paradoxical splitting of the second heart sound, and premature atrial contractions.

diseases: Marfanoid habitus-autosomal recessive intellectual disability syndrome
comment: FKTN gene is related to Mucosal telangiectasiae and Marfanoid habitus-autosomal recessive intellectual disability syndrome. The gene encodes a protein called fibronectin type III domain-containing protein, which plays a crucial role in the structure and function of connective tissue.

KIF22 is a gene that encodes for a protein involved in the process of nail plate formation. Mutations or alterations in this gene have been associated with isolated congenital onychodysplasia, a rare disorder characterized by abnormalities in finger nails.

The PLOD1 gene provides instructions for making an enzyme called procollagen-lysine, 2-oxidase, which is involved in the production of collagen. Mutations in the PLOD1 gene have been linked to Ift43-related hypochondrosarcoma and other disorders characterized by abnormalities in bone growth and development.

diseases: Difference of sex development-intellectual disability syndrome
comment: The FREM2 gene is associated with a range of symptoms, including abnormal hair patterns, and several diseases, including Ringed hair disease, Braddock syndrome, and Difference of sex development-intellectual disability syndrome.

The TRPV4 gene is a known cause of the Long thorax syndrome, which is characterized by abnormalities in the thorax and other parts of the body. It has also been associated with Brachydactyly-mesomelia-intellectual disability-heart defects syndrome.

diseases: Increased circulating brain natriuretic peptide concentration
comment: Corin is a gene that encodes for the corin enzyme. It plays a crucial role in the processing and regulation of ANP (Atrial Natriuretic Peptide) and has been associated with various cardiovascular diseases.

NOTCH2 gene mutations have been linked to Nasal dysarthria, Bifid uvula and NOTCH2-Associated Disorder. The symptoms and abnormalities associated with NOTCH2 gene mutations include nasal dysarthria, bifid uvula and other oral and palatal anomalies.
The COG5 gene is associated with Oculoskeletodental syndrome and COG5-CDG. Abnormalities in the frontal hairline are a common symptom.

diseases: 46,XX difference of sex development-skeletal anomalies syndrome
comment: The FREM2 gene is associated with abnormalities in vaginal morphology and 46,XX difference of sex development-skeletal anomalies syndrome.
CEP85L is a gene associated with bipolar affective disorder.

Association with AHR gene is not explicitly mentioned in the given associations. However, based on available information AHR gene mutation can cause Gastrocutaneous syndrome and Johnson neuroectodermal syndrome. The association of AHR gene with Multiple cafe-au-lait spots may also exist but it's not explicitly mentioned in the provided associations.

TBXT gene is linked to the development of the urogenital and intestinal systems. Mutations in this gene can lead to various abnormalities, including persistent cloaca and aphalangy-hemivertebrae-urogenital-intestinal dysgenesis syndrome.

symptoms: Reduced glycerol kinase activity in cultured fibroblasts
comment: Glycerol kinase (GK) deficiency is a rare genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to regulate glycerol levels. It can lead to abnormal circulating glycerol levels, reduced glycerol kinase activity, and adrenocortical hypoplasia, a condition where the adrenal glands do not develop properly.
PTF1A gene mutations are associated with various physical abnormalities and diseases, particularly affecting the development of the pancreas and other organs.

symptoms: cataracts with opacities at the anterior pole
comment: MIR184 is a microRNA that has been associated with several ocular abnormalities, including hypoplasia of the iris and anterior polar cataract.

diseases: Neurodevelopmental disorder with hypotonia and autistic features with or without hyperkinetic movements
comment: Mutations in the PCDH19 gene are associated with a range of neurological disorders, including epilepsy, intellectual disability, and autism spectrum disorder. The symptoms and abnormalities described above are commonly linked to mutations in this gene.

The SFTPA2 gene encodes for the heparan sulfate proteoglycan, which plays a role in the formation of the heart and lung tissue. Mutations in this gene have been associated with various abnormalities and diseases, including pulmonic regurgitation, atresia of urethra, Kallmann syndrome-heart disease syndrome, and meconium aspiration syndrome.

diseases: Abnormal circulating plasminogen activator inhibitor activity
Decreased level of tissue plasminogen activator
comment: The gene SERPINE1 encodes the protein plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 (PAI-1), which plays a crucial role in regulating fibrinolysis. Mutations or variants of this gene have been associated with various symptoms and diseases, including hemoperitoneum, abnormal circulating plasminogen activator inhibitor activity, abnormality of fibrinolysis, decreased level of tissue plasminogen activator, reduced alpha-2-antiplasmin activity, reduced plasminogen activator inhibitor 1 activity, reduced plasminogen activator inhibitor 1 antigen, and umbilical cord hematoma.

Progressive external ophthalmoplegia (PEO) is a rare genetic disorder that affects the muscles outside of the eyes. The symptoms of PEO can vary widely, but often include progressive weakness and paralysis of the extraocular muscles, which control eye movements. Other symptoms may include muscle wasting, fatigue, and exercise intolerance.

Mutations in the TCAP gene have been associated with an increased risk of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, prolonged QTc intervals, cardiac arrest, and sudden death.
FBN1 is a gene that provides instructions for making a protein called fibrillin-1. Mutations in the FBN1 gene can lead to Marfan syndrome, a disorder that affects the body's connective tissue.
Surfactant Protein C (SFTPC) gene mutation leading to respiratory issues.

FAT4 gene mutations are associated with various congenital abnormalities and diseases, including periventricular nodular heterotopia, cutaneous syndactyly of toes, bifid scrotum, bilateral choanal atresia/stenosis, irregular dentition, abnormal tracheal morphology, and caudal appendage.

The DEAF1 gene is associated with various symptoms and abnormalities, including tactile sensory seeking, abnormal sleep architecture, abnormality of pain sensation, and abnormal vocal cord morphology.
Ubiquitin protein ligase 1 (UBR1) is a gene that has been associated with several diseases and symptoms, including Anasarca, Castleman disease, and pancreatic insufficiency.

symptoms: Abnormal pigmentation of the oral mucosa
comment: JAZF1 is a gene associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and other autoimmune diseases. The symptoms, abnormalities, and diseases listed are commonly seen in patients with JAZF1 mutations or associations.

Neurodevelopmental disorder with structural brain anomalies

comment: JAG1 is a transcription factor gene that plays a critical role in the development of the liver, heart, and other organs. Mutations in the JAG1 gene have been identified as the primary cause of Alagille Syndrome, which is characterized by cholestasis (a reduction or stoppage of bile flow) among other symptoms.

PCSK9 is a gene that encodes for the low-density lipoprotein receptor, which plays a role in lipid metabolism. However, recent studies have also implicated PCSK9 in neurodegenerative diseases, including early-onset X-linked optic atrophy.

comment: NGLY1 gene is associated with a range of symptoms, abnormalities and diseases, including hand deformities, dystonia, sclerosis, oral feeding difficulties, cognitive dysfunction, bone mineral density abnormalities, liver disease, muscle weakness, speech difficulties, neurological problems, gastrointestinal problems, metabolic disorders, nutritional deficiencies, energy metabolism disorders, hormonal imbalances.
The CHSY1 gene is linked to the symptoms and abnormalities associated with synostosis of carpals/tarsals and second metatarsal-metacarpal syndrome.

diseases: Diarrhea 3, secretory sodium, congenital, with or without other congenital anomalies
comment: PERCC1 is a protein-coding gene that has been linked to various genetic disorders. The gene plays a role in regulating cellular processes, including DNA repair and cell signaling.
WBP4 is a gene that has been associated with neurodevelopmental disorders, particularly those affecting brain development and function.
CTD1 gene mutation is associated with Anotia, a congenital disorder characterized by the absence or underdevelopment of one or more ear structures.

The NCF1 gene encodes for the p47phox subunit of NADPH oxidase, which is essential for the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in phagocytic cells. Mutations or variations in this gene have been linked to several diseases and disorders characterized by abnormalities of neutrophils.
SLC18A2 is involved in the transport of dopamine, serotonin, and other catecholamines across cell membranes.

The DUX4 gene is associated with a group of genetic disorders known as myopathic emphysema and limb-girdle muscular dystrophy type 1A. The symptoms and abnormalities listed are commonly seen in individuals with these conditions.

gene: Multiple genes are associated with Short toe syndrome, but some of the most commonly implicated genes include: PTH1R, TLE4, FGF5, SMAD3, and ACAN.

Short toe syndrome is a heterogeneous disorder with multiple genetic causes.
comment: The exact mechanisms of the disorders linked to short toe syndrome are not fully understood. Research continues into the underlying genetic causes and their impact on disease pathogenesis.
KCNJ18 is a gene that codes for an inwardly rectifying potassium channel. Mutations in this gene have been associated with cardiomyopathy, specifically dilated cardiomyopathy.
The PRNP gene is linked to spongiform changes in the cerebral cortex and is associated with spongiform encephalopathy with neuropsychiatric features.

comment: The gene FREM1 is involved in the development of the facial bones and other structures. Mutations in this gene can lead to a range of congenital abnormalities and diseases, including those listed above.

symptoms: Reduced cystathionine beta-synthase activity in cultured fibroblasts
comment: CBS stands for Cystathionine Beta-Synthase, a gene that plays a crucial role in the metabolism of the amino acid methionine.
PEX7 is a gene that provides instructions for making an enzyme called alpha-oxidase. This enzyme is involved in the breakdown of phytanic acid, a type of fatty acid found in certain foods and oils.
The RNU4ATAC gene is associated with Mazabraud syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by abnormal bone growth and other skeletal abnormalities.

symptoms: Abnormal development of certain tissues or organs
Eye abnormalities such as lacrimal gland hypoplasia
comment: The SOX10 gene plays a crucial role in the development and patterning of various tissues, including the eyes, intestines, and other organs. Mutations or alterations in this gene have been linked to several congenital disorders, as seen in the provided associations.
Dopamine autoreceptor-associated protein

diseases: Bilateral tonic-clonic seizure with generalized onset
comment: The gene NEXMIF is associated with a wide range of symptoms, abnormalities, and diseases. It is an X-linked dominant gene, which means it can be inherited from either parent. The symptoms and diseases associated with NEXMIF are varied and can include seizures, muscle weakness, premature aging, eating disorders, emotional instability, and brain imaging abnormalities. In addition, individuals with NEXMIF may experience hyperactivity, increased fetal movement, slow EEG activity, abnormal consumption behavior, spasticity, balding, social isolation, self-biting behaviors, hand wringing, body rocking, stuttering, delayed motor development, and nephrotic syndrome.

GSX2 is a gene associated with various neurodevelopmental disorders and abnormalities. The specific symptoms and diseases listed are related to GSX2 mutations or variations, which can impact brain development and function.

ADSS1 is a gene that has been associated with several neurological disorders, including ALS, PPMD, FTD, and PHPN. The symptoms and abnormalities listed are commonly seen in individuals with mutations in this gene.
CTRC gene variants are associated with insulin dependent diabetes type 2, pancreatic cysts and chronic calcifying pancreatitis.
The KCTD1 gene provides instructions for making a protein called keratinocyte transmembrane domain 1, which is involved in the development and maintenance of brain structure and function.

DNAJB13 is a chaperone protein that plays a role in the proper folding and function of proteins. Mutations in DNAJB13 have been linked to various genetic disorders, including intestinal malrotation, volvulus of midgut, Martinez-Frias syndrome, and Emanuel syndrome.

diseases: Abnormality of the musculature of the hand
comment: The YARS1 gene is involved in the function of tyrosine aminotransferase, an enzyme that plays a role in the biosynthesis of the amino acid tyrosine. Mutations in this gene have been associated with various diseases and abnormalities, including profound hearing impairment, abnormality of the musculature of the hand, and macronodular cirrhosis.

diseases: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the fingers
comment: Genetic disorder associated with multiple systemic and skeletal manifestations.
CCDC89A is a protein-coding gene that has been associated with IgG4-related disease, which can cause abnormality in the orbital region.

A gene mutation in TMTC3 has been linked to multiple congenital abnormalities, including periventricular heterotopia, thin skin, abnormal heart valve morphology, retrocerebellar cysts, and shoulder dislocation. The exact mechanism by which the disease is caused is not fully understood.

diseases: Mitochondrial myopathy with reversible cytochrome C oxidase deficiency
comment: These conditions are caused by mutations in mitochondrial DNA and lead to defects in energy production within cells. The symptoms and diseases associated with these genes highlight the impact on the cardiovascular system.

The VPS13B gene is associated with an autosomal recessive form of spastic paraplegia, ectodermal dysplasia, and neurosensory deafness. Thoracic scoliosis is also linked to mutations in the VPS13B gene.

The NEK9 gene is associated with Nevus comedonicus, a rare genetic disorder characterized by the presence of comedo-type nevi (skin lesions) and abnormal skin pigmentation. The symptoms can range from freckling to more severe skin discoloration.

Mutations in the GPR101 gene have been associated with growth hormone secretion disorders and insulin-like growth factor 1 deficiency syndrome, which can lead to symptoms such as short stature and delayed puberty.

gene: Xlinked sideroblastic anemia and spinocerebellar ataxia
comment: The gene is associated with Anisocytosis, Anemia, sideroblastic, 3, pyridoxine-refractory, Hemolytic anemia, G6PD deficient (favism), Orotic aciduria, Anemia, congenital dyserythropoietic, type Ib, Iron-Refractory iron deficiency anemia, Thrombocytopenia with congenital dyserythropoietic anemia.
The FGD1 gene provides instructions for making a protein that is involved in the formation and maintenance of cartilage, which is the flexible tissue that connects bones to each other.

PF15  PUF60 mutations are known to cause Craniofacial dysmorphic syndrome with various associated features such as Duplication of phalanx of hand, Shoulder subluxation, Abnormal cricoid cartilage morphology etc.

The gene NEU1 encodes the enzyme neuraminidase, which is involved in the biosynthesis of glycoproteins and glycolipids. Mutations or deficiencies in this gene have been linked to various abnormalities and diseases.
IRF2BP2 gene is associated with Immunoglobulin A Deficiency 1 and decreased circulating IgA concentration.

The gene LMNA is commonly associated with lipomatosis, a condition characterized by the growth of abnormal fat tissue. It can also cause other symptoms such as skeletal abnormalities and neurologic problems.
A gene associated with Hematological and Lymphatic System Abnormalities
This gene is associated with Spermatogenic failure and 46XY sex reversal.
SHOX gene is associated with growth disorders, limb abnormalities and certain metabolic disorders.

TSC and BHDS are both rare genetic disorders that can cause a variety of symptoms. TSC is characterized by the growth of non-cancerous tumors in many parts of the body, including the brain, kidneys, and skin. BHDS is associated with an increased risk of developing kidney cancer, lung cancer, and other types of cancer.

diseases: Febrile seizure (within the age range of 3 months to 6 years)
Bilateral tonic-clonic seizure with focal onset
comment: CEP85L is a gene that has been associated with various neurological and psychiatric conditions. The specific symptoms and diseases listed are not exhaustive, and additional research is needed to fully understand the relationship between CEP85L and these conditions.

The FTN1 gene is associated with Idiopathic inflammatory pseudotumour, a condition that can cause abnormality in the orbital region.
This gene is associated with Epileptic encephalopathy, early infantile and Progressive microcephaly.

diseases: Laminin subunit alpha 2-related congenital muscular dystrophy
comment: The Lamina gene is associated with these diseases and symptoms. More information can be found about the individual diseases in the OMIM or ORPHA database.

Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC) is a genetic disorder that affects multiple systems in the body. The SNRPB gene is associated with TSC, which can cause various symptoms and abnormalities, including calcaneal epiphyseal stippling, anomalous rib insertion to vertebrae, rib gap, and having 10 pairs of ribs.

symptoms: progeroid short stature with pigmented nevi
comment: There is no single gene linked to the symptoms, abnormalities and diseases. These conditions have multiple genetic factors contributing to their development.

The gene ABCC9 is associated with several congenital abnormalities and diseases. The exact function of the ABCC9 gene in human development and disease is not fully understood, but it is believed to play a role in the regulation of ion transport across cell membranes.
Family member involvement in familial Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia, OMIM:13
The gene VPS13A is linked to the symptoms and diseases associated with abnormally slow thought process and isolated corpus callosum agenesis.

The MICOS13 gene is associated with a group of rare genetic disorders that affect the eyes and liver. These conditions are characterized by abnormalities in the mitochondria, which can lead to symptoms such as macrovesicular hepatic steatosis (fatty liver), bile duct proliferation (enlargement of the bile ducts), and chorioretinal hyperpigmentation (dark patches on the retina).
CACNA1H is a gene that encodes for the alpha 1A subunit of P/Q-type calcium channels. Mutations in this gene have been associated with various neurological and psychiatric disorders.
ITPA gene is linked to elevated erythrocyte inosine triphosphate concentration and reduced erythrocyte inosine triphosphatase activity.
DHX37 protein is involved in RNA processing and has been linked to X-linked abnormalities, including abnormal sex determination and XY partial gonadal dysgenesis.
The RPGRIP1 gene is associated with a range of eye disorders, particularly affecting the retina and visual acuity.
SLC25A42 gene mutation leading to cytochrome c oxidase deficiency, which can cause muscle weakness and exercise intolerance.

diseases: Stocco dos santos X-linked mental retardation syndrome
comment: -- The SMARCB1 gene is linked to these diseases. It's a tumor suppressor gene that plays a critical role in maintaining genome stability.

symptoms: Eosinophilic granuloma: abnormal skin lesions, bone pain
Rectal fistula: abnormal connection between the rectum and skin
Focal active colitis: inflammation of the colon with diarrhea and weight loss
comment: DOCK2 is a gene that has been linked to several rare genetic disorders. Mutations in DOCK2 have been identified as a cause of Eosinophilic granuloma, Rectal fistula, and Focal active colitis. These conditions are characterized by abnormal tissue growth, inflammation, and damage to the skin, bones, and digestive system.
The MCCC2 gene is associated with Propionyl-CoA carboxylase deficiency, which can lead to abnormal circulating leucine concentrations.
BCL2L1 gene is also known as APO-1, or CD79a, and plays a key role in the regulation of programmed cell death (apoptosis). Mutations in this gene have been associated with Classic Hodgkin lymphoma.

symptoms: Weakness or numbness in the arms or legs
comment: The PLAA gene provides instructions for making a protein called procollagen, alpha-1 chain, which is involved in the production of collagen, an essential structural protein found in connective tissue. Mutations in the PLAA gene have been associated with a range of musculoskeletal disorders and other conditions that affect the development of joints, bones, and other tissues.

The gene GTF2H5 is linked to bronchoconstriction, asthma, nasal polyps, and aspirin intolerance. Additionally, it is associated with secondary hypoparathyroidism due to impaired parathormon secretion.

The CCM2 gene is associated with Cerebral Lymphangiomatosis syndrome (CL), a rare disorder characterized by the growth of abnormal lymphatic vessels in the brain. It can also lead to astrocytomas, which are type of brain tumors.

KCNJ18 gene is associated with Autosomal recessive spastic paraplegia type 21 and abnormality of peripheral nerve conduction.

SECISBP2 gene encodes a selenoprotein that plays a critical role in the regulation of thyroid function, and is involved in the metabolism of glucose and amino acids. Mutations or alterations in SECISBP2 expression have been associated with various diseases, including those listed above.

comment: The gene DCT is associated with several diseases and conditions. In this context, it is linked to infra-orbital fold abnormalities and neurofacioskeletal syndromes.

The NCF1 gene provides instructions for making a protein called neutrophil collagenous peptide 1. This protein is found in the extracellular matrix of neutrophils, which are a type of white blood cell that plays a key role in the body's immune response.

The COL5A1 gene is associated with Hypermobile Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, a condition characterized by joint hypermobility and musculoskeletal abnormalities. Mutations in this gene can lead to defects in collagen production, causing symptoms such as wrist abnormalities.
The SAMD9L gene is associated with OSLAM syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by anemia and other hematologic abnormalities.

KCNJ18 is a potassium inward rectifier channel gene. Mutations in KCNJ18 can lead to impaired myocardial contractility and cardiomyopathy with dilated features.

symptoms: Symphalangism with multiple anomalies of hands and feet
comment: ARID1B is a gene that is associated with aplasia/hypoplasia of the distal phalanx of the 5th toe, symphalangism with multiple anomalies of hands and feet.

gene: /HP:Motor delay[OMIM:Mental retardation, autosomal recessive 10]/PET117/HP:Motor delay/MAXO:physical therapy
comment: This gene may be linked to the symptoms, abnormalities and diseases associated with motor delay, mental retardation, intellectual developmental disorder, and physical therapy. However, further research is needed to confirm this association.

SMC1A is an autosomal recessive gene that encodes a protein involved in the separation of chromosomes during cell division. Mutations in this gene have been linked to various diseases and symptoms, including those listed above.

gene: Multiple genes are associated with Failure to Thrive (FTT), including those listed below:
diseases: Periventricular heterotopia with microcephaly, autosomal recessive
Mitochondrial complex V (ATP synthase) deficiency, nuclear type 4A
Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency, hyperammonemia due to
Hypermetabolism due to uncoupled mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation 2
Encephalopathy, neonatal severe, due to mecp2 mutations
comment: This list is not exhaustive and there may be other genes associated with FTT. The list of genes provided here is based on the associations listed in the Mondo, HP, Maxo, OMIM, and ORPHA databases.

diseases: Focal facial dermal dysplasia type IV
comment: CYP26C1 gene is linked to Abnormal epidermal morphology and Focal facial dermal dysplasia type IV.
GLMN gene mutations are associated with multiple abnormalities and diseases, including gastrointestinal and skin manifestations.

diseases: Short distal phalanx of the 3rd finger
comment: The GNAS gene is a tumor suppressor gene that plays a crucial role in regulating cell growth and division. Mutations in the GNAS gene have been associated with a range of clinical conditions, including multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1), which can cause tumors to form in various parts of the body.

diseases: Progressive loss of facial adipose tissue
comment: LMNB2 is a gene that encodes a protein involved in the development and maintenance of fat cells. Mutations or alterations in this gene have been associated with lipodystrophy, which is a rare genetic disorder characterized by progressive loss of facial adipose tissue.
FRMD7 gene mutations are associated with an increased risk of congenital nystagmus and mildly reduced visual acuity.

diseases: Abnormality of the pancreatic islet cells
comment: YY1 is a transcription factor involved in various cellular processes, including cell proliferation, differentiation, and survival. It has been linked to several diseases and conditions, including those mentioned above.

diseases: Increased theta frequency activity in EEG
comment: Mutations in the KCNT1 gene have been associated with a range of neurological and psychiatric symptoms, including seizures, psychosis, autonomic dysfunction, and sleep disorders. The exact mechanism of KCNT1 mutations is not fully understood, but it is thought to affect the function of ion channels in neurons, leading to abnormal electrical activity and neurotransmitter imbalances.
Please note that additional information should be added to the summary.

The SLC25A12 gene is associated with several diseases and symptoms, including febrile status epilepticus and abnormal jejunum morphology. More information about these conditions can be found in the provided associations.

The PRRX1 gene plays a crucial role in the development of the face and jaw. Mutations or variations in this gene have been linked to abnormalities such as aglossia (absence of the tongue) and synotia (a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of the jaw and palate).
Hadib gene is associated with left ventricular dilatation and rigors.
SELENON is caused by mutations in the SLCO1B3 gene. Cor pulmonale can also be associated with this gene mutation.

diseases: Bone spicule pigmentation of the retina
Abnormal central response of multifocal electroretinogram
Photoreceptor outer segment loss on macular OCT
comment: The gene PRCD is associated with a range of eye diseases and abnormalities, including retinal degeneration, rod-cone dystrophy, cataract, progressive night blindness, macular degeneration, retinal atrophy, optic disc pallor, attenuation of retinal blood vessels, cystoid macular edema, abnormal electroretinogram, undetectable electroretinogram, color vision defect, keratoconus, photoreceptor outer segment loss on macular OCT, and photopsia. These conditions can lead to significant visual impairment and blindness.

HRURF (Hairless and Rooted Verb at Recombinant Fidelity) is a gene that has been linked to uncombable hair syndrome. Mutations in this gene can cause a range of symptoms, including uncombable hair, which is characterized by difficulty combing or styling the hair due to its abnormal texture and structure.
COA6 is associated with PKP2 gene mutation which can cause Left Ventricular Noncompaction and Reduced left ventricular ejection fraction.
Bile acid synthesis defects are characterized by impaired bile acid production. PBC2 is a gene associated with this condition.

The PIGL gene provides instructions for making a protein called PIGL, which is involved in the formation of the heart's valves and septa (divisions). Mutations in the PIGL gene have been identified as a cause of pulmonary valve atresia, a condition where the pulmonary valve is completely blocked.

A gene mutation or variation in the TSEN54 gene may be associated with an increased risk of developing progressive microcephaly and epileptic encephalopathy, a rare and severe form of epilepsy that affects infants.
PI Gemart syndrome

Mutations in SAMD9L gene have been associated with various hematological disorders, including Myelodysplastic syndrome and Alpha-Thalassemia myelodysplasia syndrome. The exact mechanism of how these mutations lead to disease is not yet fully understood but it is believed that they affect the function of SAMD9L protein which plays a role in regulating gene expression.

MYH9 gene mutations can lead to various disorders, including HUS, Goodpasture's syndrome, and IgA nephropathy. The gene is involved in the production of non-muscle myosin heavy chain, which plays a crucial role in cell motility and cytoskeletal structure.

The NCF1 gene provides instructions for making a protein called neutrophil collagenous peptide 1. This protein is important for the functioning of neutrophils, which are a type of white blood cell that helps to fight infection.

diseases: Elevated bronchoalveolar lavage fluid lymphocyte proportion
symptoms: Elevated bronchoalveolar lavage fluid lymphocyte proportion
comment: BTNL2 gene is associated with autoimmune diseases and has been linked to various symptoms, including enlarged lacrimal glands, increased T cell count, heart block, nasal mucosa abnormalities, conjunctiva abnormalities, dacryocystitis, parotid gland enlargement, abnormal liver parenchyma morphology, and reproductive system abnormalities.
The gene B3GALTL is linked to the symptoms, abnormalities and diseases Basan syndrome and Olmsted syndrome 2. Flexion contracture of digit is a common symptom associated with these conditions.

symptoms: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung
comment: The RET gene is a proto-oncogene that encodes for a receptor tyrosine kinase. Mutations in this gene are associated with several hereditary endocrine cancers, including medullary thyroid carcinoma, multiple endocrine neoplasia type IIA and IIB, Birt-Hogg-Dub syndrome, and familial medullary thyroid carcinoma.

diseases: WAC-related facial dysmorphism-developmental delay-behavioral abnormalities syndrome
comment: RNU4ATAC gene is associated with various developmental and physical abnormalities, including arachnoid cysts, facial dysmorphisms, and intellectual disabilities.

RPS19 is a gene that has been linked to several congenital abnormalities, including abnormal tricuspid valve physiology, bifid thoracic vertebrae, hypoplastic coccygeal and sacral vertebrae. The exact mechanisms of how this gene leads to these conditions are not fully understood but research is ongoing.
This gene is responsible for the phosphohydroxylysinuria disease
Please note that OMIM is a comprehensive database of genetic disorders, and the list of associated genes is not exhaustive.
Association between the gene GK and diseases Adrenocortical hypoplasia, Isolated glycerol kinase deficiency.

symptoms: Breast cancer symptoms: a new lump or thickening in the breast, swelling of the breast, redness or scaliness of the skin on the breast, nipple discharge or redness
Ovarian cancer symptoms: pelvic pain, bloating, frequent urination, feeling full quickly
Colorectal cancer symptoms: blood in the stool, black stools, abdominal pain, weight loss
comment: BRCA1 gene mutation is an inherited mutation that increases a woman's risk of breast and ovarian cancers.

These conditions are characterized by an abnormal accumulation of leucine in the body. PPM1K is a gene that encodes for a protein involved in the regulation of glycogen synthesis and degradation, which can lead to an imbalance in leucine metabolism.

The PTPN11 gene provides instructions for making a protein called SHP2, which plays a critical role in the development of cells. Mutations in this gene have been identified as the cause of Hutchinson-gilford Progeria Syndrome.

This gene is associated with a range of symptoms and abnormalities, including posterior pituitary agenesis, abnormal facial skeleton morphology, hypoplasia of the frontal bone, and abnormal calvaria morphology.
CRYBA4 gene mutations are associated with posterior subcapsular cataract and PRCD (Progressive Retinal Cataract)
The C8 gene is associated with decreased circulating complement C8 concentration and recurrent Neisserial infections.

The GATA2 gene is a transcription factor that plays a crucial role in the development and function of various cell types, including hematopoietic cells. Mutations or alterations in this gene have been associated with several diseases and abnormalities, including cervical neoplasms, cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, and abnormal total neutrophil count.

symptoms: Loss of ability to walk in first decade
comment: The association between SLC9A6 gene and Distal myotilinopathy is mentioned in the provided associations. It suggests that mutations or alterations in the SLC9A6 gene may be related to the development of Distal myotilinopathy, a condition characterized by loss of ability to walk in the first decade of life.

diseases: Acute encephalopathy with biphasic seizures and late reduced diffusion
comment: DOCK8 gene mutations are associated with severe viral infections, immunodeficiency, hypohidrotic ectodermal dysplasia, acute encephalopathy with biphasic seizures and late reduced diffusion.
NTRK1 is a gene that encodes for a receptor tyrosine kinase, and its mutations have been linked to various diseases and symptoms.

MMP2 gene is associated with various conditions, including osteoarthritis, Kniest dysplasia, acromegaly, hypochondroplasia and spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia congenita. The symptoms include widened metacarpal shaft, peripheral opacification of the cornea, thin metatarsal cortices, ankylosis of feet small joints and distal tapering of metatarsals.
The gene DDX59 is associated with Agenesis of canine and Proboscis lateralis, which is characterized by abnormal development of the nasal cavity.

symptoms: Eversion of lateral third of lower eyelids
Restricted or repetitive behaviors or interests
Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the cerebral white matter
comment: Also known as CRASH, this gene is also associated with other genetic conditions.
-- The gene associated with Acute pancreatitis is RNU7A --
The gene ATP7A is a copper transporter and mutations in this gene can lead to Menkes disease, which is characterized by abnormal copper levels in the body.

diseases: Epidermolysis bullosa simplex with mottled pigmentation
comment: TRPS1 is a gene that encodes a protein involved in the regulation of hair growth and skin development. Mutations in this gene have been linked to various conditions, including epidermolysis bullosa simplex with mottled pigmentation, hypotrichosis simplex, Marie Unna hereditary hypotrichosis, Graham Little-Piccardi-Lassueur syndrome, alopecia, and neonatal transient zinc deficiency.

diseases: Hump-shaped mound of bone in central and posterior portions of vertebral endplate
Enlarged epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand
Spurred metaphyses of the upper limbs
comment: TRAPPC2 gene is also known as TRAPPC2 protein which plays a crucial role in the endoplasmic reticulum-associated degradation (ERAD) pathway. Mutations or alterations in this gene have been linked to various skeletal disorders and abnormalities.
SMG8 gene mutations can lead to various congenital heart defects and other systemic abnormalities.

diseases: Amino aciduria with mental deficiency, dwarfism, muscular dystrophy, osteoporosis, and acidosis

comment: The association with ALK (Anaplastic Lymphoma Kinase) gene suggests a potential link between this gene and the development of vitreous floaters or retinal capillary malformations. However, more research is needed to confirm the exact nature of this relationship.

FTL gene mutations are linked to several neurological disorders, including Cavitation of the basal ganglia, Abnormal hindbrain morphology, and Abnormal metencephalon morphology. However, more research is needed to fully understand the relationship between FTL gene mutations and these conditions.

The FOCACD gene is associated with Fanconi anemia, a rare genetic disorder characterized by congenital anomalies, cancer predisposition, and immunodeficiency. The symptoms of Fanconi anemia include anemia, bone marrow failure, and immunodeficiency.

gene:
Multiple genes are implicated in various forms of male infertility.

Some of the key genes include:

- ZNF703: associated with spermatogenic failure and azoospermia

- TMC8: associated with chronic kidney disease, renal tubular acidosis type 2, and male infertility

- PRY2: associated with autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) and male infertility

- SLC26A1: associated with nephrolithiasis and male infertility

- SMAD9: associated with spermatogenic failure and azoospermia

- USP7: associated with male infertility, kidney stones, and polycystic kidney disease

- VEGFR3: associated with male infertility and vascular abnormalities

- CYP11B1: associated with congenital adrenal hyperplasia and male infertility

- HSD17B4: associated with 17-alpha-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase 4 deficiency, which can cause male infertility

- PDE5: associated with erectile dysfunction and male infertility

- KDM5C: associated with spermatogenic failure and azoospermia

- WDR35: associated with autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) and male infertility
diseases: Vas deferens, congenital bilateral aplasia of
comment: The exact gene responsible for a specific condition may vary depending on the individual and the underlying genetic mutation. The information provided is a general overview of some of the genes associated with male infertility and related conditions.

UNC45B is a gene associated with skeletal muscle diseases, particularly shoulder girdle muscle atrophy and muscle fiber granulofilamentous inclusion bodies. These conditions are characterized by progressive muscle weakness and wasting, especially in the shoulder girdle region.

NKX2-1 is a homeobox gene that plays a crucial role in the development of the lung. Mutations or alterations in this gene have been linked to an increased risk of developing pneumocystosis, a rare but serious opportunistic infection typically affecting people with weakened immune systems.
The gene TGM1 (Transglutaminase Mutant 1) is linked to the symptoms, abnormalities and diseases of localized epidermolytic hyperkeratosis and palmoplantar scaling skin.
Trigonocephaly-short stature-developmental delay syndrome
SNORD116 gene is associated with adult-onset nemaline myopathy and poor fine motor coordination.

The gene linked to these symptoms and diseases is Distrophin (DMD), Fibrillin-1 (FBN1) and ATP6AP2. These genes are responsible for the production of proteins that play a crucial role in maintaining muscle and bone health, as well as regulating neural activity.

diseases: Male infertility with azoospermia or oligozoospermia
comment: The SOHLH1 gene is associated with premature ovarian failure and male infertility due to its role in regulating reproductive function.

The SEMT2H gene provides instructions for making an enzyme called semithiobucolactone methyltransferase. This enzyme is involved in the degradation of certain amino acids, including phytanic acid. Mutations in the SEMT2H gene can lead to Refsum disease.
This gene is associated with several rare genetic disorders, including Oculocutaneous Albinism Type 1B and Ulnar Maturity Syndrome.
Mutations in BOLA3 can cause X-linked neurodegenerative syndrome, also known as Bertini type.
The MBL2 gene is associated with the production of mannose-binding lectin, a protein that plays a key role in the innate immune system.

diseases: Neurodegeneration due to cerebral folate transport deficiency
comment: The gene SLC19A1 is linked to the symptoms of developmental regression, Neurodegeneration due to cerebral folate transport deficiency and Epileptic encephalopathy, early infantile.

diseases: Microcephaly with epilepsy and diabetes syndrome
comment: HP is a genetic condition. Based on the associations provided, it appears that HP is linked to various diseases such as Hyperphenylalaninemia, Intellectual developmental disorder, Microcephaly, Microcephaly with epilepsy and diabetes syndrome, Diarrhea with tufting enteropathy, and Diabetes mellitus. The symptoms associated with HP include Small for gestational age.

symptoms: Abnormal ossification involving the femoral head and neck
comment: PAPP-A2 is a gene associated with Pappalardo syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects bone development. The symptoms of this disease include abnormal ossification in the femoral head and neck, wide proximal femoral metaphysis, and other skeletal abnormalities.

diseases: Synostosis involving bones of the upper limbs
Aplasia/hypoplasia involving bones of the upper limbs
symptoms: RECQL4, HP:Synostosis involving bones of the upper limbs
RECQL4, HP:Aplasia/hypoplasia involving bones of the upper limbs

comment: PHEX gene mutation is associated with X-linked Dent disease and mild global developmental delay. The PHEX gene provides instructions for making a protein called proline-rich collagen (PRC) alpha 1, which is an essential component of the development and maintenance of kidney function.
The PIGF gene is associated with Bilateral Triphalangeal Thumbs and Hypoplastic Thumb syndromes.
The SMCHD1 gene provides instructions for making a protein called SmcHD1, which is involved in the regulation of gene expression and chromatin remodeling.
Syndactyly type IV is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the fusion of two or more digits, and LMBR1 gene mutation is associated with this condition.

diseases: Foam cells with lamellar inclusion bodies
Diffuse reticular or finely nodular infiltrations
symptoms: Foam cells with lamellar inclusion bodies
Diffuse reticular or finely nodular infiltrations

comment: Multiple genes are involved in the pathogenesis of these diseases. The exact gene involved is not specified in the provided associations.

symptoms: Increased rate of premature chromosome condensation
comment: The MCPH1 gene is associated with an increased risk of cancer, particularly leukemia and lymphoma.

diseases: FADD (Familial Adenomatous Dysplasia), Autoimmune disorders (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, lupus)
comment: The gene TNFRSF13B encodes for the FADD protein, which is involved in regulating apoptosis and immune responses. Mutations or variants in this gene have been associated with FADD (Familial Adenomatous Dysplasia), as well as autoimmune disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis and lupus.

TRPV1 gene mutation has been associated with Abnormal forearm morphology, Self hugging, Stereotypic whole-body movements and Sleep-wake inversion. TRPV1 gene is a receptor that plays a role in regulating pain, temperature, and inflammation.

diseases: Incomplete cleft of the upper lip
comment: CEP120 gene is associated with multiple congenital abnormalities, including skeletal dysplasias and craniofacial malformations.
The associations indicate that the gene associated with Bulimia is related to susceptibility to bulimia nervosa and Xq12-q13.3 duplication syndrome.
The gene HTT is linked to Hemiballismus, while mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome 17 is associated with the OMIM entry. MRM2 is a related protein.
The association with MARS2 also suggests a possible interaction or linkage with the gene responsible for Growth Hormone Deficiency, type IB.

Spinocerebellar ataxia type 26 is a rare genetic disorder caused by an expansion of the CAG repeat in the ATXN8 gene. This gene encodes for the protein ataxin-8, which plays a role in regulating the movement and coordination of the body.
The HRURF gene is associated with Hypotrichosis 15, a rare genetic disorder characterized by sparse scalp hair. HRURF stands for Hairless and Recessed Eye Syndrome Factor.
Cerebral amyloid angiopathy is associated with mutations in the APP gene, not ACAD9.

The PI4K2A gene is associated with two neurological disorders: Akathisia and Hypoplastic anterior commissure. Akathisia is a movement disorder characterized by restlessness and agitation, while Hypoplastic anterior commissure is a rare brain malformation that affects the connection between the two hemispheres of the brain.

symptoms: Congenital lipomatous overgrowth, vascular malformations, and epidermal nevi
Capillary malformation of the lower lip, lymphatic malformation of face and neck, asymmetry of face and limbs, and partial/generalized overgrowth
comment: Macrodactyly is a condition characterized by excessive growth of fingers or toes. It can be associated with various genetic syndromes, including CLAPO syndrome, Hemihyperplasia-multiple lipomatosis syndrome, and Congenital lipomatous overgrowth, vascular malformations, and epidermal nevi.

diseases: Thyroid hormone resistance, generalized, autosomal dominant
comment: The THRB gene provides instructions for making a protein called thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG), which plays a critical role in the transport and regulation of thyroid hormones in the body.
Gene associated with eye abnormalities and diseases, particularly related to cornea.

diseases: Reduced branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase activity in cultured fibroblasts
Benign neoplasm of the central nervous system
symptoms: Benign neoplasm of the central nervous system
comment: CCBE1 is a protein-coding gene that has been associated with various physical abnormalities and diseases, primarily affecting the development of tissues and organs.

The gene MATN3 encodes a protein involved in cartilage formation and function. Mutations in this gene have been associated with osteoarthritis, particularly those affecting the distal interphalangeal joints, as well as Heberden nodes.

diseases: Absent microvilli on the surface of peripheral blood lymphocytes
Reduced lymphocyte surface expression of CD43
Bone marrow arrest at the promyelocytic stage
comment: The ITGA4 gene is linked to Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome (WAS).
Mutations in the ATP7A gene cause Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT), a rare genetic disorder characterized by abnormal blood vessel formation.

The KIT gene encodes for the stem cell factor receptor, which plays a crucial role in the development and function of mast cells. Mutations or aberrant expression of the KIT gene have been implicated in various disorders, including cutaneous mastocytosis and mast cell activation syndrome.

The SFTPB gene encodes for the subunit Beta (B) of Surfactant Protein B, which plays a crucial role in maintaining lung function by reducing surface tension in the lungs. Mutations or deficiencies in this gene can lead to Surfactant Metabolism Dysfunction and pulmonary abnormalities.
The gene KRT5 is associated with Epidermolysis bullosa dystrophica and Pretibial blistering.
KIF5A gene is associated with Spastic paraparetic gait and Dupuytren contracture.

The ARX gene is a critical regulator of brain development and function. Mutations in this gene have been associated with focal dystonia, a type of movement disorder characterized by involuntary muscle contractions. The ARX gene encodes the aristaless-related homeobox protein, which plays a role in neuronal migration and differentiation during brain development.

Dynein arms are crucial for the movement and function of cilia in various cells. The gene NME8 encodes a protein that is involved in the structure and assembly of dynein arms, which are essential for the motility of cilia.
The RPIA gene is associated with Ribose-5-phosphate isomerase deficiency, which leads to elevated circulating ribitol concentrations.

symptoms: Stenosis of the external auditory canal
comment: SIX1 gene mutation is linked to Auriculocondylar syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by abnormalities in the ear and other parts of the body. The condition often leads to stenosis (narrowing) of the external auditory canal.

The KCNK9 gene provides instructions for making a protein called potassium calcium-activated channel, subfamily K (KCND3). Mutations in this gene can lead to various skeletal abnormalities and conditions.
The gene PRA encodes the prolidase enzyme, which is deficient in patients with prolidase deficiency. The disease is caused by mutations in the PRA gene.
SPRED2 is a gene that has been linked to abnormalities in hair quantity and Aplasia cutis congenita-intestinal lymphangiectasia syndrome.

The ZFP57 gene is associated with a range of symptoms and diseases, including severe failure to thrive, diabetic ketoacidosis, hyperglycemia, maternal diabetes, autoimmune antibody positivity, abnormality of limbs, transient neonatal diabetes mellitus, and hypoinsulinemia. The specific relationship between the ZFP57 gene and these conditions is not fully understood and may involve complex interactions with other genetic and environmental factors.
PKD1 gene mutation is responsible for Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD), which is characterized by the presence of albuminuria.

diseases: Protuberances at ends of long bones
comment: The BRG1 gene is associated with various skeletal abnormalities and diseases, including pseudoaneurysm, Madelung-like forearm deformities, protuberances at ends of long bones, pelvic bone exostoses, peripheral nerve compression, deformed forearm bones, scapular exostoses, and femoroacetabular impingement. Tendon pain is a common symptom associated with BRG1 mutations.
MTMR14 is a gene that encodes for the protein myotonic dystrophy protein 1 (DMP1), which is involved in the regulation of muscle tone and cell growth.

SERPING1 gene is a crucial regulator of the complement system and is involved in maintaining vascular homeostasis. Mutations or variations in this gene can lead to abnormalities in C1-esterase inhibitor concentration, abnormal total hemolytic complement activity, and limbal edema.

The DAOA gene has been associated with social and occupational dysfunction, schizophrenia, negativism, and delusions. Mutations in this gene have been linked to impaired social cognition, emotional regulation, and cognitive function.

NOTCH2 gene mutations are associated with Notch2-related disorder, a condition characterized by syncope and aortic root dilatation. It is also known as NOTCH2-associated disorder or NOTCH2-related disorder.
The CNTNAP2 gene is associated with Rasmussen subacute encephalitis, a rare and severe form of epilepsy. The gene plays a crucial role in the development and function of neurons in the brain.
The ZNF335 gene is associated with isolated right ventricular hypoplasia, a rare congenital heart defect. The Bidirectional shunt and IFT56 are related to this condition.

The FMO3 gene provides instructions for making an enzyme called flavin-containing monooxygenase 3. The abnormality in this gene results in reduced activity of the enzyme, which can lead to the accumulation of trimethylamine in the body. This is associated with Trimethylaminuria (a rare genetic disorder that affects the metabolism of certain amino acids) and has also been linked to symptoms such as abdominal pain, nausea, diarrhea, and a foul odor on breath.

symptoms: Elevated urinary pyrroline hydroxycarboxylic acid level
comment: ALDH4A1 gene is associated with Lysinuric protein intolerance and Psychotic disorders.

symptoms: Decreased naive CD4-positive T cell proportion

diseases: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the fingers
symptoms: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the fingers

comment: The SGO1 gene is associated with an increased risk of developing sick sinus syndrome, a condition characterized by abnormal heart rhythms and other related symptoms.

CYP21A2 gene encodes the enzyme 21-hydroxylase, which is crucial for the production of cortisol and aldosterone from cholesterol in the adrenal glands. Mutations in this gene lead to impaired cortisol production, resulting in the accumulation of precursor molecules that can cause the overproduction of androgens.
This gene is also linked to other conditions, please refer to the ORPHA database for more information.
The gene PHACTR1 is linked to Hypotrichosis 13, Abnormal skin morphology, Infantile epileptic spasms syndrome, Hereditary coproporphyria and Acute intermittent porphyria.

diseases: Abnormal CD69 upregulation upon TCR activation
Decreased CD69 upregulation upon TCR activation
comment: MAGT1 gene is associated with impaired T cell activation and abnormal immune response, leading to various diseases such as chronic active Epstein-Barr virus infection, persistent CMV viremia, and B-cell lymphoma.
TUBA3D is a gene associated with a range of developmental abnormalities and diseases. The symptoms listed are those that have been linked to mutations or variations in the TUBA3D gene.

The TYRP1 gene is associated with Oculocutaneous albinism type 2 (OCA2), a rare genetic disorder that affects the production of melanin, resulting in white skin, light hair, and light eye color. The Ermine phenotype is also linked to this gene, which is characterized by fair skin, blonde hair, and blue or green eyes.
autosomal recessive inheritance pattern
Association with ACAN gene is inferred from various sources including Human Protein Reference Ontology (HP) and Mondo.
The PRKAR1A gene is associated with familial atrial myxoma and myxoma, intracardiac. Bacterial endocarditis may be a symptom of these conditions.

symptoms: Focal EEG discharges with secondary generalization
comment: KCTD7 is a gene that has been linked to X-linked intellectual disability, psychosis, and macroorchidism syndrome. It is characterized by focal EEG discharges with secondary generalization.

diseases: Corneal dystrophy of bowman layer, type II
Insensitivity to pain, congenital, with anhidrosis
Neuropathy, hereditary sensory and autonomic, type VIII

comment: The KRT9 gene is associated with Erythrokeratodermia variabilis et progressiva 2, Palmoplantar keratoderma, nonepidermolytic, focal 1 and Pachyonychia congenita 4.
The TNXB gene is associated with both quadricuspid aortic valve and classic-like Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

The NHLRC1 gene is linked to the formation of Lafora bodies, a hallmark of Lafora body disease. Mutations in this gene can cause early-onset Lafora body disease, a rare and severe form of epilepsy characterized by progressive myoclonic epilepsy.
The SDHD gene provides instructions for making a protein called succinate dehydrogenase subunit D, which is an enzyme that plays a critical role in the body's energy production processes.

ARL6IP6 is a gene that has been linked to various symptoms, abnormalities, and diseases. The specific symptoms and diseases listed above are associated with mutations or variations in the ARL6IP6 gene.
The CD244 gene is associated with Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) and the mentioned symptoms and abnormalities are known to be linked to this disease.
Hyperkynureninemia (HKCN) is a rare genetic disorder caused by mutations in the HKn gene. It leads to elevated levels of hydroxyky-nurenine, a toxic compound that can cause liver and kidney damage.
The FGFR2 gene is a common variant associated with cleft lip and palate, as well as other facial abnormalities.
The gene JPH3 is associated with Entropion, Ectodermal dysplasia, sensorineural hearing loss and distinctive facial features.
GALNS gene mutation is associated with Panner disease, a rare genetic disorder characterized by abnormal bone development in the elbow joint.
No symptoms are mentioned in the given associations. The gene PIK3C2A is associated with phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase, gamma class II alpha subunit, which plays a role in cell signaling pathways.
PCEA gene mutation is associated with BEST1 disease, which affects the retina and leads to abnormalities in chorioretinal pigmentation, retinal arteriolar occlusion, and pulverulent cataract.

The CACNA1H gene is associated with several conditions, including low self-esteem, abnormality of the renin-angiotensin system, punding, and elevated aldosterone:renin ratio. The exact mechanisms underlying these associations are not yet fully understood.
The PIG-A gene is associated with the PIGY syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects various systems in the body.
The given gene SLC25A42 is associated with delayed ability to walk, Usher syndrome and also Spinocerebellar ataxia.

diseases: Neoplasm of the central nervous system
comment: KLLN gene is associated with various abnormalities and diseases, including tumors, skin lesions, hearing impairment, and developmental disorders.

symptoms: Neoplasm of the genitourinary tract: urinary tract problems, kidney failure, etc.
Premature chromatid separation: abnormal cell division, chromosomal instability, etc.
comment: TRIP13 gene mutations have been associated with an increased risk of developing certain types of cancer, particularly those affecting the genitourinary system. It is also implicated in premature chromatid separation, a process that can lead to chromosomal instability and an increased risk of cancer.
DNAJB13 gene mutation associated with certain congenital airway anomalies and respiratory conditions.

The NAA10 gene provides instructions for making a protein called nucleotidyltransferase, which is involved in the production of very-long-chain fatty acids. Abnormalities in this process have been linked to certain diseases and conditions, including abnormal forehead morphology and minimal subcutaneous fat.

B3GALT6 is a gene that encodes for a transmembrane glycoprotein involved in the synthesis of keratan sulfate. Mutations in this gene have been associated with pulmonary bullae causing pneumothorax and repeated pneumothoraces.

diseases: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th finger
symptoms: A contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th finger
comment: SIN3A gene is linked to various symptoms, abnormalities and diseases. It's a tumor suppressor gene that plays a role in regulating cellular growth and proliferation.

symptoms: Decreased proportion of naive T cells
comment: The gene FOXN1 is associated with a range of immunological abnormalities and diseases.

The CARMIL2 gene is associated with recurrent cutaneous abscess formation, pyomyositis, and kerion celsi. It's worth noting that the exact relationship between the gene and these conditions may be complex and not fully understood.
NSMCE2 gene is associated with noninsulin-dependent diabetes mellitus.
The CCN2 gene is associated with IgG4-related systemic disease, which can cause abnormalities in the orbital region.
RLBP1 gene mutation is associated with a range of eye diseases and abnormalities.

diseases: Reduced number of intrahepatic bile ducts
Thickening of the tubular basement membrane
symptoms: Reduced number of intrahepatic bile ducts
Thickening of the tubular basement membrane
comment: TMEM67 gene is related to a group of disorders that affect multiple organ systems and can cause a wide range of symptoms and abnormalities.
The gene BTK (Brucella type IV) is linked to Butyrylcholinesterase deficiency, a rare genetic disorder that affects the nervous system and can cause apnea (pauses in breathing).

diseases: Angiopathy, hereditary, with nephropathy, aneurysms, and muscle cramps
Neuropathy, hereditary sensory and autonomic, type VI
comment: The gene linked to these conditions is not provided in the given associations. The OMIM (Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man) and HP (Human Phenotype Ontology) IDs are associated with multiple genetic disorders, but without further information, it is difficult to determine the specific gene associated with each condition.

KCNJ18 is a gene that provides instructions for making a protein called KCNJ18, which is part of a family of proteins involved in the function and regulation of potassium channels. Mutations in this gene have been associated with Charcot-marie-tooth disease and lower limb muscle weakness.
TMEM127 is a gene that has been linked to Paraganglioma and Carney-Stratakis syndrome, two rare diseases characterized by the development of paragangliomas, which are rare neuroendocrine tumors.
These gene is also associated with a spectrum of lymphatic abnormalities.
The gene FLG (Filaggrin) is a key regulator of the skin's barrier function.

diseases: Deafness-genital anomalies-metacarpal and metatarsal synostosis syndrome
comment: The BHLHA9 gene is associated with the Deafness-genital anomalies-metacarpal and metatarsal synostosis syndrome. It is also linked to a short hallux (a deformity of the big toe).
CD27 is a gene that has been associated with two severe diseases caused by the Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV): Encephalitis and Meningitis.

diseases: Abnormal insulin like growth factor binding protein acid labile subunit level
Reduced insulin like growth factor binding protein acid labile subunit concentration
comment: Insulin-like Growth Factor Binding Protein Acid Labile Subunit (IGFALS)

ADAMTS19 is a gene that provides instructions for making a protein called ADAMTS-19, which is involved in the formation of cartilage and connective tissue. Mutations in this gene have been associated with various congenital heart defects, including aortic valvular disease, cardiac anomalies, and other cardiovascular abnormalities.

diseases: Congenitally corrected transposition of the great arteries
comment: This gene is associated with congenitally corrected transposition of the great arteries and mesocardia.
Associated with Gastrointestinal defects and immunodeficiency syndrome. Decreased total lymphocyte count indicates a compromised immune system.
Polygenic inheritance

diseases: Trigonocephaly with short stature and developmental delay
comment: The exact gene responsible for these conditions is still being researched, but RNU4ATAC is a known gene associated with Trigonocephaly.
The gene SLC13A5 has been linked to various conditions affecting the teeth, skin, and nervous system. The exact function of this gene is not yet fully understood.
The IL12A-AS1 gene is associated with gait disturbances. It is also linked to papillary tumors of the pineal region and pineocytoma.

NSMCE3 gene mutations are associated with Griscelli syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects the immune system and causes impaired skin pigmentation, reduced delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions, and other symptoms.
The GDF1 gene is associated with Abnormality of abdominal situs and Right isomerism. Further research is required to determine the full extent of its role in these conditions.

diseases: Abnormal left ventricular outflow tract morphology

comment: Atpk3 gene mutation is associated with atypical pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration.
the above associations have been linked to nasal congestion. They can be linked for further studies on the disease or symptoms.

The PAX6 gene is involved in eye and kidney development. Mutations in this gene are associated with a range of developmental disorders, including Bartter syndrome type 3, Bruck syndrome 1, and abnormalities of the sclera.
The MAFA gene is associated with an increased risk of developing insulinoma, a rare tumor of the pancreas that produces excess insulin.
associated with various diseases such as Epidermolysis bullosa, Rapp-Hodgkin syndrome, Pachyonychia congenita, type 1, Haim-Munk syndrome and Erythrokeratodermia variabilis et progressiva 5

diseases: Thiamine metabolism dysfunction syndrome 5 (episodic encephalopathy type)
Mitochondrial complex IV deficiency, nuclear type 22

comment: The gene ATXN8 is associated with Machado-Joseph disease, a rare autosomal dominant disorder characterized by progressive cerebellar ataxia and sensory abnormalities.
ARL6IP6 is a gene that has been linked to familial cylindromatosis and telangiectasia of the skin.

NKX2-6 is a transcription factor that plays a crucial role in the development of the heart. Mutations or alterations in NKX2-6 have been linked to congenital heart block, a condition characterized by abnormal electrical activity in the heart that can lead to abnormally slow heart rates. Abnormal heart valve physiology is often associated with congenital heart defects, including those caused by mutations in NKX2-6.
TMEM240 is a gene associated with Spinocerebellar ataxia type 21, characterized by intermittent microsaccadic pursuits.

diseases: Abnormality in nasal septum cartilage morphology
symptoms: HP: Abnormal cartilage and bone development
comment: The UBA1 gene is a gene that provides instructions for making a protein called ubiquitin-associated protein 1. Mutations in this gene have been associated with several skeletal abnormalities, including chondrodysplasias and chondritis.

diseases: Delayed closure of the anterior fontanelle
symptoms: Delayed closure of the anterior fontanelle
comment: The H19 gene is a non-coding RNA that has been linked to various developmental and growth disorders.

diseases: Male infertility with large-headed, multiflagellar, polyploid spermatozoa

comment: The gene G6PC1 is associated with combined oxidative phosphorylation deficiency 2, anemia and patent ductus arteriosus.

Anosynaline nucleotide hydrolase 1 (ANO1) gene mutation can cause posterior cerebral artery stenosis and Moyamoya disease, leading to various symptoms such as stroke, transient ischemic attack, seizures, vision loss, and cognitive impairment.

The CORO1A gene is associated with cardiac complications in patients infected with varicella zoster virus, particularly after live vaccination. The exact mechanism of how the gene contributes to these complications is not fully understood but it may be related to its function in regulating the immune response.
No direct information on symptoms is available. Please refer to the associated HP IDs for more details.

The MYD88 gene is a key component of the Toll-like receptor (TLR) signaling pathway, and mutations or alterations in this gene have been implicated in various diseases, including autoimmune disorders. Cryoglobulinemia refers to the presence of abnormal proteins that precipitate at low temperatures, while monoclonal immunoglobulin M proteinemia involves an overproduction of a specific type of antibody.

The NOTCH2 gene is associated with an increased risk of developing Parkinson's disease and Progressive Supranuclear Palsy, two neurodegenerative disorders characterized by rigidity. The exact mechanism by which NOTCH2 contributes to these conditions is not fully understood.

Mutations in the PAX6 gene are associated with various developmental abnormalities, including renal hypoplasia and urethral valves. PAX6 is a transcription factor that plays a crucial role in the development of several organs, including the kidneys and urinary tract.

diseases: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the distal phalanx of the 5th toe
Short distal phalanx of the 5th toe
Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the distal phalanges of the toes
Abnormality of the distal phalanx of the 5th toe
comment: ARID1B is a gene that encodes for an enzyme involved in chromatin remodeling. Mutations in this gene have been associated with a range of developmental and genetic disorders, including the conditions listed above.
The CCR2 gene is associated with cystic fibrosis like pulmonary diseases.
The CTNNB1 gene is linked to the mentioned symptoms, abnormalities and diseases. However, a detailed analysis of its function in human health is needed for further insights.

[The IL2RA gene encodes the common subunit of the interleukin-2 receptor, which plays a critical role in the regulation of the immune response. Mutations or variations in this gene have been associated with abnormal lymphocyte proliferation and various autoimmune diseases.
The TMPRSS6 gene is associated with iron regulation and erythropoiesis, suggesting that variants in this gene may lead to disturbances in iron metabolism and related conditions.
a genetic disorder that affects the lung function and is characterized by an abnormality in the SERPINA1 gene
FGFRL1 gene mutations have been associated with various skeletal dysplasias, including Thanatophoric Dysplasia (TD) and Thanatodactyly-Tanotemic dysplasia (TDT).

symptoms: Decreased circulating complement factor I concentration

comment: The THSD4 gene is associated with an increased risk of descending aortic dissection and familial aortic dissection. It is also linked to aortic aneurysm and two types of familial thoracic aortic aneurysms (familial thoracic 6 and familial thoracic 11).

diseases: Male hypergonadotropic hypogonadism-intellectual disability-skeletal anomalies syndrome
comment: AROG gene mutations are associated with isolated ulnar hemimelia and male hypergonadotropic hypogonadism-intellectual disability-skeletal anomalies syndrome.

diseases: Decreased Expression of GPI-anchored proteins on the cell surface

comment: KIF23 is a gene associated with Hemosiderinuria and Anemia, dyserythropoietic congenital, type III.

Broad distal phalanx of the hallux
comment: HOXD13 gene mutations are associated with various limb abnormalities, including broad distal phalanges of the thumb and hallux, 2nd-5th toe middle phalangeal hypoplasia, and type D brachydactyly.

TRAF7 gene mutations have been associated with Pulmonary Alveolar Microlithiasis (PAM), a rare lung disease characterized by the accumulation of tiny calcium crystals in the lungs, leading to progressive pulmonary function impairment.

Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare inherited disorder that affects the absorption of fats and fat-soluble vitamins. It is caused by mutations in the ABCG gene, which plays a crucial role in the transport of bile salts across cell membranes.

The CALPA3 gene is associated with Calpain-3-related limb-girdle muscular dystrophy R1, Muscular dystrophy, limb-girdle, autosomal recessive 23 and Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy 3. It also has a connection to Pontocerebellar hypoplasia, type 1E through elbow flexion contracture.
NOTCH2 gene is associated with Paraplegia, Spastic paraplegia-glaucoma-intellectual disability syndrome and Spastic paraplegia-facial-cutaneous lesions syndrome.
The BRCA1 gene is a tumor suppressor gene that plays a critical role in maintaining the integrity of DNA. Mutations in the BRCA1 gene can lead to an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancers.
The TBX5 gene is associated with Atrioventricular septal defect and Unroofed coronary sinus. Interatrial communication may also be a symptom of this genetic condition.
The SLC26A2 gene is associated with various skeletal and facial abnormalities, as well as certain types of tumors.
TRAF7 is a gene that has been linked to craniopharyngioma, which is a type of brain tumor that occurs near the pituitary gland.
Genetic disorder associated with RNU7-1 gene. The symptoms and diseases listed are related to this genetic condition.
The gene FLCN (Fibroblast Growth Factor 4

Peg-like appearance of bones in leg
comment: AIFM1 gene associated with various skeletal abnormalities and diseases, including Abnormal glial cell morphology, Abnormal astrocyte morphology, Abnormal middle ear reflexes, Peg-like central prominence of distal tibial metaphyses and Cone-shaped capital femoral epiphysis.

Acrodysostosis 2 with or without hormone resistance
Global developmental delay, lung cysts, overgrowth, and wilms tumor
Neurodevelopmental disorder with impaired intellectual development, hypotonia, and ataxia
Neurodevelopmental disorder with microcephaly, hypotonia, nystagmus, and seizures
comment: No specific gene has been linked to all of these conditions. Multiple genes are likely involved in each condition.

LIPC (Lipoprotein Lipase) gene is associated with an increased level of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol in the blood, which can lead to a condition called hyperalphalipoproteinemia. This condition may increase the risk of certain diseases, such as cardiovascular disease.

diseases: Brachyolmia 4 with mild epiphyseal and metaphyseal changes
comment: The gene HSD3B2 is associated with adrenal hyperplasia, congenital, due to 3-beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase 2 deficiency. Additionally, it has been linked to Brachyolmia 4 with mild epiphyseal and metaphyseal changes and Cortisone reductase deficiency 2.

Note: MAFB is associated with Multicentric carpotarsal osteolysis syndrome, but the relationship between bilateral renal atrophy and MAFB is not as clear-cut. Further research is needed to confirm the link.
The KIAA1506 gene is associated with Leber congenital amaurosis and retinitis pigmentosa, both of which are devastating eye diseases that can lead to blindness.
The gene ANK3 is linked to the symptoms, abnormalities and diseases mentioned. Specifically, it is associated with ANK3-related intellectual disability-sleep disturbance syndrome.

The CYP7A1 gene is involved in the metabolism of vitamins A and E. Mutations or variations in this gene can lead to abnormalities in the levels of these vitamins in the body, resulting in various health issues.
All three diseases mentioned are linked to the gene SLC25A4. SLC25A4 encodes for the thyroid transcriptome protein, which plays a role in cell growth and differentiation.
The HOXD13 gene is associated with Type D Brachydactyly, a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of fingers and hands.
The FRAS1 gene is associated with Recombinant 8 syndrome, which can cause abnormalities in the anus.

diseases: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the phalanges of the thumb
comment: CNOT1 is a gene that has been linked to various genetic disorders and diseases, including those mentioned in the provided associations. These include enzyme deficiencies, developmental disorders, and metabolic disorders.
The KCTD1 gene is associated with Branchiogenic deafness syndrome.

diseases: Impaired renal tubular reabsorption of bicarbonate
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms
comment: IL12A-AS1 is a long non-coding RNA that has been linked to several skin diseases, including those characterized by pustules. It is thought to play a role in regulating inflammation and immune responses.

The SCGB3A2 gene is associated with airway hyperresponsiveness, a condition characterized by an exaggerated response to stimuli in the airways. Additionally, research suggests that this gene may also be involved in non-Mendelian inheritance patterns, which deviate from the traditional pattern of Mendelian inheritance.
HJV stands for Hemojuvelone Mutant protein, a gene that codes for an alpha-globulin protein.
The BCOR gene provides instructions for making a protein called BCL6 corepressor. The mutation in this gene is associated with BICRA Syndrome, which affects the development of the brain and skull.
This gene encodes a protein that is involved in the regulation of iron metabolism and has been linked to cyanosis, benign familial infantile seizures.

comment: The DOK7 gene is associated with Congenital short bowel syndrome
