Neurodevelopmental disorder with absent language and variable seizures
Neurodevelopmental disorder with spasticity, cataracts, and cerebellar hypoplasia
Combined osteogenesis imperfecta and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome 2
Combined osteogenesis imperfecta and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome 1
symptoms: Severe growth deficiency-strabismus-extensive dermal melanocytosis-intellectual disability syndrome
Peripheral neuropathy with variable spasticity, exercise intolerance, and developmental delay
Congenital disorder of glycosylation, type I
Intellectual developmental disorder with persistence of fetal hemoglobin
Microcephaly, short stature, and impaired glucose metabolism 2
Primary microcephaly-mild intellectual disability-young-onset diabetes syndrome
Neurodevelopmental disorder with absent language and variable seizures
Neurodevelopmental disorder with spasticity, cataracts, and cerebellar hypoplasia
Combined osteogenesis imperfecta and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome 2
comment: Multiple genes are associated with various conditions, but some of the most notable ones include COL1A1, MMP8, MMP9, MGP, SMAD3, TGFBR1, TGFBR2, SMAD4, and others.

The NRAS gene is linked to various abnormalities and diseases, including Abnormal choroid plexus morphology, Linear nevus sebaceous, Numerous congenital melanocytic nevi, and Decreased T cell apoptosis.

diseases: Rajab interstitial lung disease with brain calcifications 2
Hypotonia, ataxia, developmental delay, and tooth enamel defect syndrome
Congenital disorder of glycosylation, type Iy
Neurodevelopmental disorder with or without hyperkinetic movements and seizures, autosomal dominant
Mitochondrial complex IV deficiency, nuclear type 14
Hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathy type 5
comment: SYNGAP1 gene mutations lead to a range of developmental disorders, including intellectual disability, epilepsy, and brain abnormalities. The gene plays a critical role in the regulation of neuronal development and function.
The WNT3 gene is associated with two types of congenital abnormalities: abnormal scapula morphology and peripheral pulmonary vessel aplasia.
GNB2 gene mutation may cause abnormal PR interval and sick sinus syndrome, which are cardiac conditions.

A mutation in the FEZF1 gene has been linked to anosmia (inability to smell) and is a common cause of Waardenburg syndrome type 2E. Additionally, this mutation may also be associated with indifference to pain and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.
Glucosamine-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency (GALACTOSAEURIA) due to mutations in the GALA gene, not GLA.
The gene SLC25A21 is linked to abnormalities in urinary pyrimidine and quinolinic acid levels, indicating potential involvement in certain diseases.

diseases: Sensorineural hearing loss-early graying-essential tremor syndrome
comment: No additional information available.
The TRPS1 gene is associated with BICRA syndrome, a rare genetic disorder. The symptoms and abnormalities listed are commonly found in individuals with this condition.
This gene is associated with Agenesis of cerebellar vermis, a rare congenital disorder characterized by the incomplete development of the cerebellum.
Mutations in the GATA3 gene are associated with MOMO syndrome, which is characterized by abnormal thyroid development and function.
JAG1 gene mutations are associated with both Neurocutaneous melanocytosis and Parana hard skin syndrome, which present with generalized hyperpigmentation.
The KLF15 related protein (KLLN) is associated with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD)
GJA1 gene is associated with certain types of sclerodactyly, a condition characterized by hardening and thickening of the skin on the fingers and hands.

NLRP3 is a member of the NACHTLAF5 family, which plays a key role in regulating inflammasome-mediated responses to various stimuli. Mutations or variations in the NLRP3 gene have been associated with various inflammatory and autoinflammatory disorders.
Note: FIBP stands for Fibrodysplasia Ossificans Progressiva, a rare genetic disorder.

symptoms: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 3rd finger
Broad distal phalanx of the toes
comment: MED25 is a gene that encodes a protein involved in chondrocyte differentiation and mineralization. Mutations in this gene have been associated with various skeletal abnormalities, including contractural arachnodactyly, joint laxity, and broadened distal phalanges.

diseases: Abnormality of the upper respiratory tract
comment: LAMC2 gene mutations are associated with various congenital and developmental disorders, including Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the bladder, Pyoderma, and Abnormality of the upper respiratory tract.
SPINK5 gene mutations are associated with certain diseases and abnormalities, including brittle scalp hair and hypernatremic dehydration.

Note: TP63 is a tumor suppressor gene that plays a role in the development of various organs and tissues, but it's also implicated in autism susceptibility. The exact relationship between TP63 and autism is not fully understood, but it's clear that abnormalities in this gene can lead to facial dysmorphisms and other developmental issues.

symptoms: Hyperkeratosis of the palms and soles
comment: KRT74 is a gene that encodes for the protein Keratin 74. Mutations in this gene have been linked to Palmoplantar hyperkeratosis, Clouston Syndrome, Analgesic therapy and epidermolytic Palmoplantar keratoderma.
The CCR2 gene is linked to spontaneous neonatal pneumothorax and cystic disease of the lung.
The RSPO1 gene is linked to dosage-sensitive sex reversal, a condition characterized by abnormalities in sexual development. It affects the development of male and female reproductive organs.
The gene MADD (MutY homolog domain containing protein) is linked to MAFA, a gene that is associated with the mentioned diseases and symptoms.
The gene HMGCR is linked to 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA lyase deficiency, a rare genetic disorder that can cause cardiac arrest.

The FBLN5 gene is associated with several skin conditions and features, including premature aging of the skin, particularly around the eyes and face, and abnormal morphology of cutaneous elastic fibers.

diseases: Mental retardation, X-linked, syndromic, Hedera type
comment: The gene linked to these symptoms and diseases is FMR1. It is responsible for Fragile X syndrome, a genetic disorder caused by an expansion of the CGG repeat in the FMR1 gene.
EDARADD gene is associated with Anodontia which is a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of teeth.
Mutations in MYD88 can lead to impaired immune function and increased susceptibility to infections, which may contribute to the development of cryoglobulinemia.

diseases: Aplasia of the proximal phalanges of the hand
symptoms: Aplasia of the proximal phalanges of the hand
comment: TRIO Gene - The TRIO gene is associated with a group of rare genetic disorders characterized by abnormalities in the development of hands and arms.

KCNJ13 is a gene that codes for an inwardly rectifying potassium channel subunit. Mutations in KCNJ13 have been associated with various eye disorders, including peripheral retinal degeneration, snowflake vitreoretinal degeneration, and optically empty vitreous.

diseases: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 17-alpha-hydroxylase deficiency
Distal renal tubular acidosis 3, with or without sensorineural hearing loss
comment: The gene KCNJ18 is associated with several disorders that affect electrolyte balance and hormone regulation. Mutations in this gene can lead to abnormal potassium levels, hormonal imbalances, and other symptoms.
The gene ANGPTL6 has been linked to Moyamoya disease and Transient Ischemic Attack

MFSD8 is a gene associated with a group of ocular diseases, including red-green color vision deficiency (dyschromatopsia), bull's eye maculopathy, rapidly progressive retinopathy, and perifoveal ring of hyperautofluorescence. The exact function of the MFSD8 protein is not well understood, but it is thought to be involved in the regulation of melanosome trafficking in photoreceptor cells.
RSPRY1 is a gene that has been linked to several ear-related abnormalities and diseases, including arthrogryposis, distal, type 2B, piebald trait, osteoma of middle ear, and hairy ears.

diseases: Congenital muscular dystrophy type 2 (DMD2), Alpha-dystroglycanopathy, MIM:232200
comment: DPM2 is a gene that codes for the DPM2 protein, which plays a crucial role in the formation of the dystrophin-glycoprotein complex. Mutations in this gene are associated with Congenital Muscular Dystrophy type 2 (DMD2) and Alpha-dystroglycanopathy.
The EBF3 gene is associated with pain insensitivity and central neurocytoma.

diseases: Partial duplication of the distal phalanx of the hallux
comment: The CANT1 gene is associated with certain genetic disorders. The exact symptoms and diseases can vary depending on the individual and the severity of the condition.

KIF7 is a gene that provides instructions for making a protein called KIF7. Mutations in the KIF7 gene have been associated with anencephaly, a serious birth defect characterized by the absence of a significant portion of the brain and skull.
normal erythroblast heterochromatin

The BRCA1 gene is a tumor suppressor gene that helps repair damaged DNA. Mutations in this gene can lead to an increased risk of breast, ovarian, and other cancers. The symptoms associated with BRCA1 mutations include:

The HRAS gene is a known oncogene that can cause various types of cancer and other diseases when mutated or overexpressed. In the context of Linear Verrucous Nevus Syndrome, mutations in the HRAS gene are thought to contribute to the development of skin lesions and tumors.

Mutations in the TUBB3 gene are associated with Congenital Muscular Dystrophy of Udd (CMDUD), a rare and severe form of muscular dystrophy. The gene codes for the protein tubulin, which is essential for the structure and function of microtubules in cells. Abnormalities in this protein can lead to muscle weakness, wasting, and other systemic complications.

The HBA1 gene provides instructions for making the alpha-globin subunit of hemoglobin, a protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen throughout the body. Mutations in this gene can lead to reduced or absent production of healthy hemoglobin, resulting in thalassemia.

diseases: Edema of the dorsum of hands
comment: KLHL40 is a gene that has been associated with a group of disorders known as Klippel-Feil syndrome, which includes myofibrillar myopathy and other skeletal abnormalities. The exact mechanism by which KLHL40 contributes to these conditions is not fully understood.
The ATP2A1 gene is associated with third-degree atrioventricular block, developmental and epileptic encephalopathy, and cardiomyopathy.

Note: G4PA is a gene that has been associated with various forms of dystonia, including leg, arm, and craniofacial dystonia. Abnormal posturing is also a common feature in some individuals with this genetic variant.
The RNU4ATAC gene is associated with Mazabraud syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects the skeletal system.

diseases: Depletion of mitochondrial DNA in liver
comment: The POLG2 gene provides instructions for making a protein called polymerase gamma, which is essential for the proper functioning of mitochondria. Mutations in this gene have been linked to various diseases and abnormalities, including ventricular bigeminy and depletion of mitochondrial DNA in liver.

symptoms: Abnormalities in bone development and mineralization
comment: SLC34A3 gene is involved in the regulation of phosphate reabsorption in the kidneys, which is essential for maintaining normal vitamin D levels and bone health. Mutations in this gene can lead to Vitamin D-dependent rickets type 2B and thin bony cortex.

diseases: Increased rate of premature chromosome condensation
comment: None
The RNF168 gene is associated with the symptoms, abnormalities, and diseases of Bronchitis and Mounier-Khn syndrome.

DHX37 is a DNA helicase gene that has been associated with ovarian gonadoblastoma, a rare type of germ cell tumor. It is also linked to the genetic mutations involved in gonadal dysgenesis and infertility.

diseases: Abnormality of the musculature of the limbs
comment: RASA1 is a gene that encodes for a protein involved in the regulation of blood pressure and vascular development.

The gene SFXN4 is associated with Hypersegmentation of neutrophil nuclei (HP) and Undritz anomaly. Hypersegmentation of neutrophil nuclei is a rare condition where the neutrophils in the blood have more than 5 lobes, while Undritz anomaly is a congenital disorder characterized by an abnormal development of the body's tissues.
This gene is associated with X-linked hypophosphatemia, a rare genetic disorder characterized by impaired phosphate reabsorption in the kidneys, leading to low phosphate levels in the blood.

symptoms: Absent inner and outer dynein arms
comment: DNAAF3 is a rare genetic disorder. The gene that causes this disease is the DNAH3 gene, which codes for a protein called Dynactin subunit 3. This protein plays a crucial role in the movement of cilia by binding to microtubules and interacting with dynein arms.

The gene ATXN8 is linked to Spinocerebellar ataxia type 26 and Dysmetric saccades. It is an autosomal dominant disorder that affects the cerebellum, leading to symptoms such as dysmetric saccades, which are abnormal eye movements.

diseases: Spinal muscular atrophy-progressive myoclonic epilepsy syndrome
comment: FKBP14 is a gene that provides instructions for making a protein calledFKBP14, which is involved in various cellular processes. Mutations in this gene have been linked to high-frequency sensorineural hearing impairment,Cone-rod dystrophy and hearing loss 2, and Spinal muscular atrophy-progressive myoclonic epilepsy syndrome.
PITTS-1 protein is a scaffold protein that plays a critical role in regulating the Wnt/-catenin signaling pathway, which is essential for normal brain development.
GJB6 gene mutation linked to several ear and foot abnormalities.
Decreased total monocyte count

The MYH9 gene provides instructions for making a protein called non-muscle myosin heavy chain 9. Mutations in this gene can lead to the formation of abnormal proteins, which can cause various diseases and symptoms.
Genetic disorder associated with nail abnormalities and skin conditions.
The MEN1 gene is a tumor suppressor gene, and mutations in this gene are associated with an increased risk of developing multiple endocrine neoplasias, including pituitary adenomas.

symptoms: Epidermolysis bullosa simplex with muscular dystrophy
comment: DUX4 is a transcription factor that plays a crucial role in the development and maintenance of epithelial cells. Mutations in DUX4 have been associated with several rare genetic disorders, including Congenital ichthyosiform erythroderma and Xeroderma pigmentosum variant.

diseases: Focal cognitive seizure with deja vu/jamais vu
comment: Dependence receptor 5 (DEPDC5) is a gene associated with various neurological disorders, including focal cognitive seizures, abnormal movements during sleep, psychic epileptic aura, and cortical dysplasias.

Mutations in the KANSL1 gene are associated with speech apraxia, developmental delays, intellectual disability, and seizures. It is also linked to Rolandic epilepsy, which is a type of epilepsy that affects children and is characterized by seizures that occur on one side of the body.
COX11 gene mutation may lead to various physical abnormalities.

diseases: Very long chain fatty acid accumulation
symptoms: Very long chain fatty acid storage disorder
comment: ACBD5 gene is associated with Very Long Chain Fatty Acid (VLCFA) disorders, which can lead to symptoms such as falls and ear abnormalities. Additionally, it may be linked to prominent ear helix.

The gene PSDH (Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Subunit E) is linked to symptoms, abnormalities and diseases. The gene encodes for a subunit of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, which plays a critical role in energy metabolism.

REC114 is a gene that has been associated with multiple reproductive issues, including the formation of multiple pronuclei during fertilization, abnormal embryonic development, and repeated implantation failure. The exact mechanism by which REC114 affects fertility is not fully understood, but it is thought to be involved in regulating cell division and DNA repair.
FOXI3 is a transcription factor gene that has been associated with multiple conditions, including LUMBAR syndrome, Neurofibroma, and Skin tags.
The PRKAR1A gene is associated with Carney complex, type 1 and Myxoid subcutaneous tumors.

The gene GRHL3 (Griselbach rare homeobox like protein 3) is associated with several abnormalities and diseases, including Lip pit, Paramedian lip pit, Speech articulation difficulties, and Lower lip pit.

CTC1 is a gene associated with various gastrointestinal and ocular abnormalities, including esophageal stenosis, intestinal bleeding, gastrointestinal telangiectasia, blepharitis, skin vesicles, and white hair.

diseases: Posterior synechiae of the anterior chamber
comment: Mir-204 is a microRNA that has been associated with several ocular diseases. It plays a role in regulating various cellular processes, including cell growth and differentiation.

PEX12 gene mutation is associated with Refsum disease, a rare genetic disorder that affects the nervous system and leads to abnormalities in visual electrophysiology, CSF metabolite concentrations, and amino acid levels.
The FBN1 gene provides instructions for making a protein called fibrillin-1, which is involved in the formation of elastic fibers found in connective tissue.

symptoms: Hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathy type V
comment: TRPV3 gene is associated with hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathy type V (HSAN V) and also has a link to anhidrosis.

symptoms: Broad proximal phalanges of the hand
comment: The CDKL5 gene is associated with a range of neurological and developmental disorders.
The SDHD gene is a tumor suppressor gene, mutations in which are associated with Carcinoid Syndrome and Pulmonary Carcinoid Tumors.

symptoms: Deformity of the external ear,deformity of the external nose,deformities of the fingers and toes
comment: TWIST2 is a zinc finger protein that plays a crucial role in development. Mutations in this gene have been associated with several disorders characterized by sparse or absent eyelashes, as well as other abnormalities such as eye, ear, and skeletal defects.

The PHS1 gene provides instructions for making an enzyme called phosphohydrolase 1, which is involved in the breakdown of certain amino acids. Mutations in this gene have been identified as the cause of Phosphohydroxylysinuria.

diseases: Hyper-IgE syndrome 2, autosomal recessive, with recurrent infections
Severe combined immunodeficiency, autosomal recessive, T cell-negative, B cell-negative, NK cell-negative, due to adenosine deaminase deficiency
Hyper-IgE recurrent infection syndrome 4, autosomal recessive
Hyper-IgE syndrome 6, autosomal dominant, with recurrent infections
T-B+ severe combined immunodeficiency due to CD3delta/CD3epsilon/CD3zeta
Hyper-IgE recurrent infection syndrome 3, autosomal recessive
Autosomal dominant hyper-IgE syndrome due to STAT3 deficiency
Severe combined immunodeficiency with sensitivity to ionizing radiation
Combined immunodeficiency due to ZAP70 deficiency
comment: Multiple genes are involved in these diseases, including but not limited to RAG1, RAG2, IL7R, STAT3, and CD3E.
STR6 is a gene that encodes a protein involved in organogenesis and development. Mutations in this gene have been linked to various congenital abnormalities and developmental disorders.

diseases: Neurodevelopmental disorder with cerebellar atrophy and motor dysfunction
Seizures, early-onset, with neurodegeneration and brain calcification
comment: The gene ARX ( Arrestin-like 1) is linked to the symptoms, abnormalities, and diseases mentioned in the associations. It's a gene that provides instructions for making a protein called arrestin-like 1, which plays a crucial role in brain development and function.
NOD2 gene mutation is associated with various inflammatory and autoimmune disorders, including Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, and other conditions listed in the association table.

diseases: Congenital nephrotic syndrome of the fetal kidney
comment: This gene is linked to LRTOM1, a protein that plays a critical role in kidney development and function. Mutations in this gene have been associated with Nail-patella syndrome, congenital nephrotic syndrome of the fetal kidney, and hypercalciuric nephrocalcinosis.
The CD244 gene is associated with digital flexor tenosynovitis and carpal tunnel syndrome.
The gene SLC35B2 is linked to limb dystonia, a disorder that affects the movement and muscle tone in the arms and legs.

DUX4 is a gene that has been linked to various muscular and systemic disorders, including Pure Mitochondrial Myopathy. It's worth noting that scapular winging can be a symptom of different conditions, and DUX4 mutations may not necessarily cause all symptoms mentioned above.

This gene is associated with Osteoporosis-oculocutaneous hypopigmentation syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by low bone density and skin/eye pigmentation abnormalities, including hypopigmentation of hair.

symptoms: Abnormal number of dense granules in platelets
comment: The JPHN2 gene is associated with an increased risk of Hereditary Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (HPNH), a rare blood disorder characterized by spontaneous, recurrent nocturnal hemolysis. The condition also often presents with epistaxis and abnormal number of dense granules in platelets.

diseases: Atrial septal defect-atrioventricular conduction defects syndrome
comment: The NCF1 gene is linked to Abnormal cardiac septum morphology and Atrial septal defect-atrioventricular conduction defects syndrome.
The MBL2 gene is associated with Mannose-Binding lectin, which plays a role in the immune system's ability to fight infections.
The FAT4 gene is associated with irregular dentition and familial anetoderma, which is a rare skin disorder characterized by the absence of sweat glands on certain areas of the body.

symptoms: Tooth with serrations or sharp edges
comment: CKAP2L is a gene that has been associated with several skeletal abnormalities and diseases. The symptoms listed are some of the characteristics that have been reported in individuals with CKAP2L-related disorders.

diseases: Distichiasis with congenital anomalies of the heart and peripheral
comment: Combined oxidative phosphorylation deficiency 39 is not directly linked to HEPHL1, it's actually OMIM: Combined oxidative phosphorylation deficiency 39
The RNU4ATAC gene is associated with Platyspondyly. The OMIM entry Avascular necrosis of femoral head, primary, 2 also mentions RNU4ATAC in its association.

The SMAD2 gene is associated with vertebral artery abnormalities, including aneurysms and tortuosity. This suggests a possible genetic link between SMAD2 mutations and the development of these vascular conditions.

diseases: Hyperammonemia due to N-acetylglutamate synthase deficiency
comment: The gene linked to the symptoms, abnormalities and diseases is N-acetylglutamate synthase (NAGS), which causes Hyperammonemia.

gene:
Various genes are implicated in these conditions. Some of them include: 

 STXBP1 for STXBP1-related encephalopathy 

 PEX2 and PEX5 for Congenital lactic acidosis, Saguenay-Lac-Saint-Jean type 

  MTOCD for Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease, classic form 

  UBE3A for Angelman syndrome due to maternal 15q11q13 deletion 

 and many others as listed in the HP:EEG with abnormally slow frequencies annotations.
comment: These conditions are often complex and involve multiple genetic and environmental factors. This list is not exhaustive and may not include all the genes and diseases associated with these conditions.

The ALG12 gene is involved in the synthesis of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchors, which are essential for attaching proteins to the cell membrane. Mutations or alterations in this gene have been linked to various diseases and conditions.
SMARCAD1 gene mutations are associated with a group of rare genetic disorders characterized by skin and joint abnormalities.
FOXP2 gene mutation is linked to the development of ectodermal dysplasia, sensorineural hearing loss, and distinctive facial features, which are also associated with entropion.

The AGL gene encodes for the glycogen debranching enzyme, which plays a crucial role in breaking down glycogen in the liver and muscles. Mutations in this gene can lead to Congenital Glycogen Storage Disease Type 1 (CGSD Type 1), a rare genetic disorder characterized by impaired glycogen breakdown, resulting in hypoglycemia, muscle weakness, fatigue, and progressive muscle wasting.
SCARF syndrome

ADAMTS17 gene mutation can lead to ectopia lentis, a condition characterized by the displacement of the lens in the eye. The exact function of ADAMTS17 is still unclear, but it has been implicated in the development and maintenance of the extracellular matrix in various tissues.

diseases: Osteoporosis, childhood- or juvenile-onset, with developmental delay
Spinal muscular atrophy with congenital bone fractures 2
Mitochondrial complex I deficiency, nuclear type 25
Respiratory distress syndrome in premature infants
comment: The gene associated with these conditions varies by OMIM entry. Some genes are not specified.

diseases: Hyalid Collagenosis (HP:Incomplete partition of the cochlea type II)

comment: ADAMTS17 is a gene that encodes for the ADAMTS-17 protein, which plays a crucial role in the development and maintenance of the eye. Mutations or alterations in this protein have been linked to several eye-related disorders, including Iridodonesis, Ectopia lentis, Microspherophakia, and Phakodonesis.

The PIGV gene provides instructions for making a type of glycoprotein called polyisoprenylglycerol phosphatidylinositol glycan (PIG-P), which is an anchor for a type of carbohydrate called sialic acid. In people with PIGY syndrome, the PIGV gene mutation disrupts the normal functioning of this anchor, leading to abnormal glycosylation of proteins and lipids.
Also associated with FNIP1 gene.

symptoms: Abnormal morphology of the conjunctival vasculature
comment: The GNAQ gene is a rare genetic mutation that can cause acromegaly, a disorder characterized by abnormal growth hormone production. It also increases the risk of glaucoma and affects the morphology of the conjunctival vasculature.

diseases: Peg-like central prominence of distal tibial metaphyses
symptoms: Peg-like central prominence of distal tibial metaphyses

diseases: Hemosiderosis, pulmonary, with deficiency of gamma-A globulin
comment: IRF2BP2 gene is associated with Immunoglobulin A Deficiency 1, Hemosiderosis, pulmonary, with deficiency of gamma-A globulin and Gamma-A-Globulin, defect in assembly of. IRF2BP2 gene is involved in the regulation of IgA production.
ANKRD55 is a protein-coding gene that has been associated with rheumatoid arthritis and overlap myositis.

The ASXL1 gene is associated with Orofacial cleft 10, a condition characterized by the presence of a unilateral cleft palate. The gene plays a role in the development and formation of facial structures.

symptoms: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 3-beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency
comment: The MAGEL2 gene is linked to premature adrenarche, a condition where the adrenal glands start producing sex hormones at an early age. It can also be associated with Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 3-beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency, a rare genetic disorder that affects the production of cortisol and other steroid hormones.

The SPG2 gene provides instructions for making a protein called spg2p, which is involved in the regulation of spermatogenesis. Mutations in the SPG2 gene have been associated with male infertility and azoospermia.
Somatic mosaicism associated with various types of cancer and tumors.

symptoms: Decreased erythrocyte nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide-cytochrome b5 reductase activity
comment: Note: CYB5R3 is an enzyme gene, not a protein-coding gene. It encodes for the cytochrome b5 reductase enzyme.
IRF2BP2 is a gene associated with Psoriasiform dermatitis. It is also linked to other conditions such as Mycosis fungoides and Mental retardation associated with psoriasis.

diseases: Abnormal upper to lower segment ratio
Increased upper to lower segment ratio
Curved linear dimple below the lower lip
comment: FGD1 gene mutation can lead to a range of symptoms and abnormalities, including cervical spine hypermobility, abnormal segment ratios, curved linear dimples, lozenge-shaped umbilici, and genital abnormalities.

EFEMP2 is a gene that has been linked to various cardiovascular and urogenital abnormalities, including pulmonary artery aneurysm, vascular tortuosity, hypoplasia of the diaphragm, arterial tortuosity, urethral diverticulum, small bowel diverticula, and multiple bladder diverticula. The symptoms associated with EFEMP2 mutations include diverticula, aneurysms, tortuosity, and hypoplasia.
Gene associated with Pollakisuria, Abnormality of urine homeostasis, Hyperoxaluria and Increased urine 4-hydroxy-2-oxoglutarate level.

The MICLN1 gene is associated with Microlissencephaly-micromelia syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by severe intellectual disability and physical abnormalities, including coarse facial features.
The CLRN2 gene is a known cause of deafness and abnormal vestibular function.

symptoms: Ichthyosis-Mental retardation syndrome with large keratohyalin granules in the skin
comment: NIPAL4 gene is associated with Ichthyosis-Mental retardation syndrome, also known as generalized ichthyosis. This condition is characterized by skin abnormalities, including large keratohyalin granules in the skin, and mental retardation.
FLCN gene mutation can cause isolated right ventricular hypoplasia

Bach2 protein plays a role in regulating immune responses and T-cell development. Mutations in the BACH2 gene have been associated with severe combined immunodeficiency, a condition characterized by impaired immune function.
NEU1 gene is linked to abnormalities in glycosylation processes.

diseases: Osteoarthritis of the small joints of the hand
Impairment of activities of daily living
Absent epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand
Shortening of all middle phalanges of the toes
Shortening of all distal phalanges of the toes
symptoms: Short tubular bones of the hand
comment: TRPV4 is a gene that encodes a member of the transient receptor potential vanilloid 4 (TRP) family, which are ion channels involved in various cellular processes. Mutations or variants in this gene have been associated with several conditions, including musculoskeletal and skeletal disorders.
Mutations in the BCL11A gene are associated with a range of symptoms and diseases, including Splenic infarction, Increased red cell sickling tendency, HbS hemoglobin, and Severe infection.
TUBB gene is associated with generalized hirsutism, Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome and hypertrichosis lanuginosa congenita.
Mutations in the BMPR1A gene have been associated with Orofaciodigital syndrome IX, a rare genetic disorder characterized by abnormalities of the teeth, digits, and other facial features.
ANKRD55 gene mutations are associated with abnormal metatarsal morphology and Spondyloepimetaphyseal dysplasia with joint laxity, leptodactylic type.

USHL1 gene provides instructions for making a protein called calmodulin, which is involved in various cellular functions. Mutations in this gene have been linked to Usher syndrome type 1G (USH1G), a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of the inner ear and the brain.

diseases: Abnormal CSF aspartate family amino acid concentration
symptoms: Homocystinuria, a disorder in which an amino acid called homocysteine builds up in the body,
Stroke or blood clots in small blood vessels throughout the body (thrombophlebitis),
comment: The gene ADK encodes for an enzyme called adenosine kinase.
No comment

GPR101 is a G-protein coupled receptor that has been associated with the development of functional gonadotropic adenoma, which can cause galactorrhea. It is also linked to pituicytoma, another rare endocrine tumor.

Note: The gene SLC3A2 is associated with Hyperlysinuria with hyperammonemia and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome. However, it's worth noting that the relationships between genes, diseases, and symptoms can be complex and multifaceted. This information is based on available associations in HP (Human Proteome) database and OMIM (Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man) database.
The PRR12 gene is associated with Torus palatinus, a common congenital anomaly of the jaw and also Microcornea-glaucoma-absent frontal sinuses syndrome.
The AIRE gene is a crucial regulator of central tolerance, and its dysfunction has been linked to autoimmune diseases.
PNPLA6 gene mutations are associated with Spinocerebellar atrophy and Abnormal antitragus morphology.
SUMF1 is a gene that has been associated with various genetic disorders, including those mentioned above.
The gene HDAC9 is linked to Postauricular skin tag and Question mark ear. These conditions are characterized by the presence of skin tags on the ears or unusual ear shapes.
MEGF10 is a gene that has been associated with diaphragmatic paralysis.

diseases: Mastocytosis with Skin and Lymph Node Manifestations

comment: As the CYP21A2 gene provides instructions for making an enzyme called 21-hydroxylase, mutations in this gene can lead to a deficiency in the production of this enzyme. This results in an accumulation of precursor molecules that are normally converted into cortisol and aldosterone.
The LIPC (Lipoprotein lipase) gene is associated with increased levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol, which can lead to Hyperalphalipoproteinemia 1, a rare genetic disorder.
TNFRSF11A gene mutations are associated with conditions that affect bone density and tooth development, leading to skeletal abnormalities, tooth fragility, and other musculoskeletal issues.
NOTCH2 gene mutation causes NOTCH2NLC disease which is associated with kinetic tremor, Brunner syndrome and hereditary essential tremor.

diseases: Abnormalities of placenta or umbilical cord
comment: Mutations in the ATP8A2 gene have been linked to cystic fibrosis, as well as other gastrointestinal and respiratory issues. Additionally, individuals with cystic fibrosis are at increased risk of abnormalities in the placenta or umbilical cord, while intractable diarrhea is a common symptom of the condition.

The TP53 gene is a tumor suppressor gene that plays a crucial role in preventing cancer development. Mutations in the TP53 gene can lead to various cancers, including Li-Fraumeni syndrome, which is associated with multiple types of cancer and other symptoms like progeria.

symptoms: EEG with series of focal spikes
comment: The SYT1 gene is associated with various neurological disorders and physical abnormalities. In this case, it's linked to focal epilepsy and abnormal location of the eyebrow.
Note: The genes associated with the conditions listed are not exhaustive and may vary depending on the specific condition. Additionally, some conditions may have multiple genes involved.

diseases: Abnormal circulating atrial natriuretic peptide pro-hormone concentration
comment: The gene TNNT2 encodes for the cardiac muscle protein troponin T type 2, which plays a crucial role in regulating cardiac muscle contraction. Mutations or alterations in this gene have been associated with various cardiovascular diseases and abnormalities.
The C12orf57 gene is associated with Short 2nd toe and Lens luxation.
Mutations in the JPH1 gene have been associated with both familial hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome.

STAT2 is a gene that encodes a protein involved in the signaling pathway of interferons, which play a role in immune response and inflammation. Abnormalities in this gene have been associated with various autoimmune and inflammatory disorders.
RNU4ATAC is a gene associated with Nemaline myopathy, a type of muscular dystrophy. Breech presentation is also linked to this gene.

Mutations in the TFAP2A gene are associated with a range of congenital anomalies and diseases. The TFAP2A gene provides instructions for making a protein called T/ASP, which is involved in the regulation of cell growth and differentiation during embryonic development.

symptoms: glycogen accumulation in muscle fiber lysosomes
comment: This gene is linked to glycogen storage disease due to muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency.
Note: The gene BMPR1A is linked to multiple conditions. Citrullinemia type II and DNM1L-related encephalopathy are not directly linked to this gene.
C14orf39 is a pseudogene, not an actual functional gene. It's often referred to as a 'decoy' or 'false positive' due to its association with several human phenotypes and diseases.

symptoms: Abnormal blood monovalent inorganic cation concentration
comment: KCNE3 gene mutations are associated with familial hypokalemic periodic paralysis, which can lead to symptoms such as muscle weakness and fatigue, as well as abnormal electrolyte concentrations.
The SCN9A gene is associated with pain perception. Mutations in this gene have been linked to various types of pain, including anal and jaw pain.
associated with Autosomal dominant brachydactyly type Ib (ARID)
Mutations in the BRCA1 gene increase the risk of breast and ovarian cancer.

The gene JPHN2 has been linked to Idiopathic Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (IPAH), a type of pulmonary hypertension that is characterized by high blood pressure in the arteries of the lungs. Chronic hemolytic anemia, a condition where the red blood cells are destroyed faster than they can be made, has also been associated with this gene.

diseases: Dilated vestibule of the inner ear
symptoms: Dilated vestibule of the inner ear
comment: The GREB1L gene is associated with a range of symptoms and abnormalities, including cochlear nerve aplasia, fetal polyuria, nonketotic hypoglycemia, sirenomelia, dilated vestibule of the inner ear, abnormal semicircular canal morphology, and abnormal inner ear nerve morphology.
mutations in KANSL1 have been associated with early infantile epileptic encephalopathies, particularly those characterized by focal seizures.

The SCNM1 gene provides instructions for making a protein that is involved in the development of certain structures within the body. Mutations in this gene have been linked to Orofaciodigital syndrome XIX, which is characterized by extra digits, facial abnormalities, and other systemic features.
No additional information available

The IL2RA gene is linked to several conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis and other autoimmune diseases. It plays a crucial role in the regulation of T cells, which are an essential part of the immune system.
The HCN1 gene is associated with an increased risk of obsessive-compulsive disorders and 47,XYY syndrome.

TSHZ1 gene mutations are associated with DAW1 syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by recurrent lower respiratory tract infections, chronic cough, and cardiac abnormalities including mitral atresia and sinus venosus atrial septal defect.

NACC1 is a gene that has been associated with several neurological disorders, including nocturnal seizures, apneic episodes in infancy, and cerebral white matter hypoplasia. These conditions are often characterized by developmental delays, respiratory distress, and white matter abnormalities.
ADAMTSL1 gene is associated with various congenital conditions and anomalies.

The XPC gene provides instructions for making a protein called XPC, which plays a role in repairing DNA damage caused by ultraviolet (UV) light. Mutations in the XPC gene can lead to impaired DNA repair and an increased risk of developing actinic keratosis.

This gene is responsible for encoding the Propionyl-CoA carboxylase enzyme, which plays a crucial role in the metabolism of certain amino acids, including leucine. Deficiency in this enzyme leads to impaired metabolism, resulting in abnormal circulating leucine concentrations and related symptoms.
A gene associated with Renal Tubular Dysgenesis, oligohydramnios

diseases: Impaired ability to form peer relationships

comment: Paramyotonia congenita is a rare genetic disorder that affects the muscles and can cause symptoms such as muscle stiffness, respiratory difficulties, skin sensitivity, and hyperkalemia. The PIEZO1 gene mutation is responsible for this condition.
Autosomal dominant syndrome, characterized by periauricular skin pits and abnormal morphology of the periauricular region.

diseases: Coloboma of macula with type B brachydactyly
Ventriculomegaly with defects of the radius and kidney
comment: FEZF1 is a transcription factor gene that plays a crucial role in brain development, especially in the formation of thalamorectal progenitor cells. Mutations in FEZF1 have been associated with various developmental disorders, including renal agenesis, schizophrenia, and coloboma of the macula.

The NALCN gene is associated with Ring chromosome 8 syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by physical abnormalities, including round ears. The association between the NALCN gene and this condition highlights the importance of genes in determining our physical characteristics and susceptibility to certain diseases.

The gene GALT (galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase) is linked to Galactosialidosis, a rare genetic disorder that affects the metabolism of galactose. Corneal opacity is a common symptom of this disease.
Genetic mutations in PEP45 gene have been associated with various autoimmune disorders and bone marrow failure syndromes.
The gene MRTFA (myocilin-related transmembrane protein F homolog) is associated with abnormal T cell proliferation and otitis externa.

The FMR1 gene is a mutation-linked gene associated with Fragile X syndrome, which can cause various physical and developmental abnormalities, including macroorchidism in postpubertal males and congenital macroorchidism in infancy.

diseases: Reduced brain N-acetyl aspartate level by MRS
comment: SDHAF1 gene mutations are associated with a range of neurological and developmental disorders.
FREM2 gene is associated with tracheal stenosis and congenital respiratory-biliary fistula, indicating a potential link to respiratory and digestive system abnormalities.
Thrombospondin type 1 domain containing 1

diseases: Paternal uniparental disomy of chromosome X syndrome
comment: The SDHAF1 gene is associated with Paternal Uniparental Disomy of Chromosome X syndrome, which can lead to moderate global developmental delay in children.
TMEM127 is associated with an increased risk of pheochromocytoma, a rare type of tumor that affects the adrenal gland.
Chitayat syndrome is caused by mutations in the CHIT1 gene.
This gene is associated with Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH) and Laryngeal Neuroendocrine Tumors.

diseases: Short distal phalanx of the 3rd finger
comment: GNAS gene mutations are associated with several disorders, including Pheochromocytoma and Hyperparathyroidism, not mentioned in this text.

SLC26A2 is also known as SLC26A2 gene. It has been associated with McKusick-Kaufman syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by polyhydramnios (excess amniotic fluid), intellectual disability, and other symptoms.

diseases: Aplasia of the distal phalanx of the 2nd finger
Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the distal phalanx of the 3rd finger
Aplasia of the distal phalanx of the 3rd finger
symptoms: Aplasia of the distal phalanx of the 2nd finger
Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the distal phalanx of the 3rd finger
Aplasia of the distal phalanx of the 3rd finger

diseases: Metachromatic leukodystrophy due to saposin B deficiency
comment: The SAP gene provides instructions for making the Saposin A protein, which is involved in the breakdown of certain lipids in the body. Mutations in this gene can lead to various diseases and symptoms.
JAZF1 gene is associated with Cheilitis, Oral submucous fibrosis and Plummer-Vinson syndrome.
Involved in DNA damage response, may be linked to increased AFP levels
The NPHS2 gene is associated with Alport syndrome, a genetic disorder that affects the type IV collagen in the body. This condition can cause hearing loss, kidney disease, and eye abnormalities.
A gene mutation associated with Lymphatic malformation 9.

The HSD11B1 gene plays a crucial role in the metabolism of cortisol and aldosterone. Mutations or variations in this gene can lead to impaired function, resulting in reduced production of these hormones.
Mutations in the TGFBR3 gene are associated with several types of corneal dystrophies, leading to abnormalities in the structure and function of the cornea.

The gene F9 encodes for the protein factor IX, which plays a crucial role in blood clotting. Mutations or deficiencies in this gene can lead to Hemophilia A, a genetic disorder characterized by prolonged bleeding and increased risk of gastrointestinal angiodysplasia.

The gene NDE1 is associated with several conditions, including abnormalities in fontanelle morphology and dislocation of the hip. The exact relationship between NDE1 and these conditions may vary depending on the specific disease or disorder being studied.

diseases: Neurodevelopmental disorder with cerebellar atrophy and motor dysfunction
Seizures, early-onset, with neurodegeneration and brain calcification
comment: The gene BCDO2 is linked to the symptoms, abnormalities and diseases mentioned in the associations.

SREBF1 is a gene that encodes for a transcription factor involved in lipid metabolism and cell growth. Mutations or alterations in the SREBF1 gene have been associated with an increased risk of developing certain diseases, including fibrocystic lung disease and erythematous oral mucosa.

The ALS2 gene is associated with primary lateral sclerosis, a rare and progressive neurological disorder. It is also linked to juvenile spastic tongue, a condition characterized by abnormal muscle tone in the tongue.

diseases: Elevated red cell adenosine deaminase activity
comment: The PTPN22 gene is involved in immune system regulation, and mutations in this gene have been linked to various autoimmune disorders.

diseases: Respiratory distress syndrome in premature infants
comment: RNU4ATAC is a gene that has been linked to respiratory distress syndrome in premature infants. The gene is associated with symptoms of premature birth, including respiratory distress syndrome.

diseases: Contractures, congenital, torticollis, and malignant hyperthermia
symptoms: Malignant hyperthermia (a rare but life-threatening medical emergency)
comment: ZBTB42 is a transcription factor that plays a crucial role in the development and patterning of the musculoskeletal system. Mutations in ZBTB42 have been linked to various congenital abnormalities, including arthrogryposis multiplex congenita and its associated syndromes.
The HTRA1 gene is associated with cervical spondylosis and status cribrosum, which are conditions affecting the spine.

symptoms: Abnormal ossification involving the femoral head and neck
comment: ACVR1 gene mutations are associated with Femoral Head and Neck dysplasia and other skeletal abnormalities.
The gene KIF1C is associated with Spinocerebellar ataxia, autosomal recessive 30 and Titubation.

The ALDH2 gene is responsible for encoding the aldehyde dehydrogenase 2 enzyme, which helps break down alcohol. Variants of this gene can lead to impaired alcohol metabolism, resulting in symptoms such as facial flushing and acute alcohol sensitivity.
The AR gene mutation is associated with X-linked hypogonadism and hydrocephalus-obesity-hypogonadism syndrome.
A mutation in the PRRT2 gene is associated with Focal head nodding automatism seizure and Self-limited infantile epilepsy.
PUF60 gene mutations are associated with various skeletal abnormalities and increased risk of certain diseases.

symptoms: Abnormal anatomic location of the heart
comment: The PIEZO2 gene is associated with various symptoms, abnormalities, and diseases, including Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, primitive reflex, fixed facial expression, abnormal anatomic location of the heart, absent phalangeal crease, limited wrist extension, and firm muscles.
This gene is associated with Sensory axonal neuropathy and Charcot-Marie-Tooth peroneal muscular atrophy, X-linked, with aplasia.
The ALDOB gene provides instructions for making an enzyme called aldolase B, which is necessary for the body to metabolize fructose.
The gene PCDH19 is associated with Status epilepticus without prominent motor symptoms

diseases: Left aortic arch with cervical origin of the right subclavian artery

comment: PLEC gene mutations cause a range of developmental and systemic abnormalities, including skin, musculoskeletal, and gastrointestinal symptoms.
The NCF1 gene is associated with Chronic Pulmonary Obstruction and Pulmonary disease, chronic obstructive.

diseases: Lower motor neuron syndrome with late-adult onset
comment: The CHCHD10 gene is associated with Lower motor neuron syndrome with late-adult onset, which presents with abnormal sensory nerve conduction velocities.

diseases: Glycogen storage disease due to glycogen branching enzyme deficiency
comment: The GBE1 gene provides instructions for making an enzyme called glycogen branching enzyme. This enzyme is involved in the breakdown of glycogen, a complex carbohydrate stored in the liver and muscles.
Linked to familial focal epilepsy with variable foci.

KCNH5 gene mutations are associated with familial epilepsy, particularly the benign familial neonatal epilepsy (BFNE) and early infantile epileptic encephalopathies. The KCNH5 gene encodes for the Kv11.1 potassium channel subunit, which plays a crucial role in regulating neuronal excitability and synaptic plasticity.

diseases: Megaloblastic anemia Due To Dihydrofolate Reductase Deficiency
comment: a type of anemia caused by a deficiency in the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase, which is necessary for DNA synthesis and cell division.
Phenobarbital embryopathy
IRF2BP2 is linked to decreased circulating total IgM, immunodeficiency 33 and MHC class II deficiency 5.
COLEC11 is a gene associated with Terminal osseous dysplasia-pigmentary defects syndrome and Depressed nasal tip.
associated with congenital secretory diarrhea
Toffeln-Ora et al (2009) reported a novel gene mutation in the TOE1 gene in an individual with XXY/46,XX mosaicism, ovotesticular development of testes and female external genitalia.
The gene associated with the symptoms, abnormalities and diseases is PRNP.

symptoms: Focal sensory seizure with auditory features
comment: A gene associated with focal sensory seizures with auditory features in the context of epilepsy.

The gene KY is not a recognized gene in medical literature. However, the symptoms and diseases associated with it may be linked to other genes or genetic disorders. Further research and investigation are needed to determine the underlying cause of these conditions.
FGFR2 mutation affects the development of the facial bones and can lead to abnormalities such as cleft lip and palate, and abnormal nasal septum morphology.

symptoms: Palmoplantar pustulosis: Painless blisters or pus-filled bumps on the palms and soles.
Geographic tongue: Red patches on the surface of the tongue, often accompanied by inflammation and atrophy of the papillae. (geographical appearance)
Erythematous plaque: A type of skin lesion characterized by a red, flat patch on the skin.
comment: The AP1S3 gene is associated with various conditions including palmoplantar pustulosis, geographic tongue and erythematous plaques. The exact mechanisms behind these associations are not well understood but it's worth noting that alterations in the AP1S3 protein have been implicated in several diseases.

The ZP2 gene plays a crucial role in the formation of the zona pellucida, a layer surrounding the oocyte. Mutations or abnormalities in this gene have been linked to oocyte maturation defects and thin zona pellucida.
The ASXL1 gene is associated with Congenital fibrinogen deficiency and Anaphylactic shock, while Solar urticaria may also be linked to this gene.
Note: The association between SNORD116 and Adult-onset nemaline myopathy is based on the provided Orpha association. In reality, there might be other genes or factors that contribute to this disease.

diseases: Necrotizing encephalomyelopathy, subacute, of leigh, adult
symptoms: Acroosteolysis (a condition characterized by the loss of osteoclasts in the bone tissue)
comment: WNK1 gene is associated with both Foot acroosteolysis and Necrotizing encephalomyelopathy, subacute, of leigh, adult. WNK1 stands for With No Kidney 1, a gene that plays a critical role in sodium and potassium homeostasis.

Phosphoinositide-3-kinase, catalytic, class II alpha polypeptide (PIK3C2A) is a gene that provides instructions for making one part of the enzyme phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K). The PI3K enzymes play critical roles in many cellular processes, including cell signaling pathways and the regulation of cell growth and division. Mutations in the PIK3C2A gene have been associated with Abnormality of glycosaminoglycan metabolism and Tissue ischemia

The FANCI gene is associated with Fanconi anemia, a rare genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to repair DNA damage. It can lead to various abnormalities and diseases, including small intestinal stenosis (narrowing of the intestine) and problems with the pituitary gland.
The gene EP4 is linked to the symptoms, abnormalities and diseases mentioned above.

The ALG10B gene is associated with a range of symptoms and diseases, including Torsade de pointes (a type of abnormal heart rhythm) and Notched T wave (a characteristic electrocardiogram pattern). The exact mechanism by which the ALG10B gene contributes to these conditions is not fully understood.
The ALG14 gene provides instructions for making an enzyme called alpha-N-acetylglucosaminidase. This enzyme plays a critical role in the breakdown and recycling of carbohydrates within cells.

The gene KLF1 (Krppel-like factor 1) is a transcription factor that plays a crucial role in the regulation of gene expression involved in hematopoiesis, osteoblast differentiation, and erythropoiesis.

diseases: Ventricular arrhythmias due to cardiac ryanodine receptor calcium release deficiency syndrome
symptoms: Cardiac ryanodine receptor calcium release deficiency syndrome
comment: The RYR2 gene provides instructions for making a protein called the ryanodine receptor 2. This protein is found in the heart muscle cells (cardiomyocytes) and plays a critical role in regulating the flow of calcium ions into the cell.

diseases: Abnormality of the third metatarsal bone
comment: The PNPLA1 gene is associated with a range of neuromuscular disorders, including Neuromyotonia, and other symptoms. PNPLA1 mutations have been linked to abnormalities in the third metatarsal bone and exercise-induced leg cramps.

THSD4 gene variants have been associated with various conditions, including cardiovascular and connective tissue disorders. The exact mechanisms of how THSD4 affects these conditions are not fully understood but may be related to the function of thrombodulin, a protein involved in blood coagulation.
SRPX2 gene mutation associated with centrotemporal focal spike waves on EEG
PTRH2 gene is associated with Congenital contractural arachnodactyly and other skeletal abnormalities.

TRPS1 gene is associated with both Aplasia/Hypoplasia affecting the eye and Trisomy 12p syndrome. The TRPS1 gene provides instructions for making a protein called tricho-facio-epicyclic keratodermatosis 1, which is involved in the development of hair follicles, teeth, and other tissues.

MKS1 gene is linked to various abnormalities and diseases including Olfactory lobe agenesis, Elevated amniotic fluid alpha-fetoprotein, Ambiguous genitalia in both males and females. Note: This information may not be comprehensive or up-to-date. Further research should be done for accurate information.

Note: The OMIM (Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man) numbers are used to identify specific genetic disorders. Arhgef1 is a gene that has been associated with increased transitional B cell proportion and certain immunodeficiencies.

diseases: Diaphragmatic defects, limb deficiencies, and ossification defects of skull
comment: Also associated with Abnormality of the diaphragm (HP)

diseases: Maternal uniparental disomy of chromosome 6 syndrome
comment: Note: WNT4 is a gene that codes for a protein involved in the regulation of bone density and testosterone production. The associations suggest that mutations or alterations in this gene may be linked to increased serum testosterone levels, as well as specific genetic syndromes such as maternal uniparental disomy of chromosome 6 syndrome and polyembryoma.

PMP22 is a gene that codes for a protein involved in the maintenance of myelin, the fatty substance that surrounds and protects nerve fibers. Mutations or alterations in this gene have been associated with various neurological disorders, including the ones listed above.

symptoms: Neuronal loss in the cerebral cortex
Degeneration of the lateral corticospinal tracts
Weakness due to upper motor neuron dysfunction
Decreased activity of mitochondrial complex II
comment: CHCHD10 is a gene that codes for a protein involved in the maintenance of mitochondrial function and structure. Mutations in this gene have been associated with several neurological disorders, including amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), spinal muscular atrophy, and frontotemporal dementia.
The DYT11 gene is associated with Woodhouse-Sakati syndrome, a rare form of dystonia.
None known

The UNC80 gene is associated with an autosomal recessive disorder that affects multiple systems in the body. It can cause a range of symptoms, including a conspicuously happy disposition, profound static encephalopathy, arachnodactyly, hyperesthesia, and facial hypotonia, among others.
The PPARGC1A gene is associated with IgG4-related systemic disease, which can cause abnormalities in the orbital region.
The gene DZIP1L is associated with Systemic capillary leak syndrome.
SCN11A is a gene that encodes for the sodium channel Nav1.7, which plays a crucial role in pain transmission.

TCOF1 is a gene that has been linked to several craniofacial abnormalities and developmental disorders, including squamosal suture synostosis, hypoplasia of the pharynx, and abnormal parotid gland morphology.
A gene that affects multiple physical characteristics related to hair growth.
The RNU4ATAC gene is associated with Joubert syndrome and Cerebellar vermis hypoplasia.

diseases: Abnormal curvature of the vertebral column
Abnormality of skeletal muscle fiber size
comment: STAC3 gene mutations have been associated with a range of developmental abnormalities, including those mentioned above.
CEP57 is a gene associated with temporal lobe abnormalities and vaginal neoplasms.

diseases: Pigment deposition in the trabecular meshwork
comment: Familial primary open-angle glaucoma associated with abnormal extracellular matrix protein expression.
The HRG gene is associated with decreased levels of histidine-rich glycoprotein, which can lead to recurrent thromboembolism.

diseases: Myopathy due to myoadenylate deaminase deficiency
Glycogen storage disease due to lactate dehydrogenase deficiency
comment: KCNJ18 is a gene that codes for an ion channel. Mutations in this gene have been linked to several conditions, including rhabdomyolysis, myopathy due to myoadenylate deaminase deficiency, and glycogen storage disease due to lactate dehydrogenase deficiency.
The GALM gene is associated with Hypergalactosemia, a rare genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to metabolize galactose, a sugar found in milk and other dairy products.

symptoms: Erlenmeyer flask deformity of the femurs
Delayed pneumatization of the mastoid process
comment: FGFR2 gene mutations are commonly associated with Apert syndrome and Cleidocranial dysplasia. These genetic disorders can cause a range of skeletal abnormalities, including those listed above.

diseases: Familial dilated cardiomyopathy with conduction defect
comment: These diseases are caused by mutations in the LMNA gene.

diseases: Congenital total pulmonary venous return anomaly
comment: Mutations in the Jag1 gene, which codes for a transcription factor involved in vascular development, are commonly associated with Hypoplastic aortic arch syndrome and Congenital total pulmonary venous return anomaly.
IL17F gene is linked to Abnormality of temperature regulation and related diseases

The MYF5 gene is associated with abnormalities in the development of the eyes, particularly with hypotropia and hypodeviation. These conditions can lead to misalignment of the eyes, resulting in symptoms such as strabismus and amblyopia.

diseases: Abnormality of the distal phalanx of the thumb

comment: Both Cri-du-chat and Smith-Magenis syndromes are caused by deletions on the short arm of chromosome 5. These genetic disorders can cause a variety of symptoms, including self-mutilation.
RTL1 gene is associated with Kagami-Ogata syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by abnormalities in the development of the skeleton, particularly affecting the shape of the ribs.

Note: CARMIL2 is a gene associated with recurrent cutaneous abscess formation, pyomyositis, and kerion celsi. The exact mechanism of how this gene contributes to these conditions is not fully understood.

The DSPP gene is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes a protein called dentin phosphoprotein. Mutations in the DSPP gene have been associated with Dentinogenesis imperfecta, a genetic disorder characterized by abnormal tooth development.

diseases: Mitochondrial myopathy with reversible cytochrome C oxidase deficiency
comment: The gene ETV2 is a transcription factor that plays a crucial role in the development and function of various tissues, including the cardiovascular system. Mutations in the ETV2 gene have been implicated in several diseases, including mitochondrial myopathy with reversible cytochrome C oxidase deficiency, Paris-Trousseau thrombocytopenia, Miyoshi myopathy, and hemangiopericytoma, malignant. These diseases are characterized by abnormalities of the cardiovascular system.

The gene linked to these conditions varies by association. For example, Dent disease 2 is associated with the CLCN5 or CLCN7 gene, while Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, periodontal type, has multiple genetic associations. Hereditary hyperekplexia is often caused by mutations in the NKCC1 gene. X-linked Ehlers-Danlos syndrome can be caused by mutations in the COL3A1 or COL5A2 genes, and OCLN (occludin) is a protein that is often associated with junctional epidermolysis bullosa.

diseases: Mosaic variegated aneuploidy syndrome 7 with inflammation and tumor predisposition
comment: Association of DICER1 with Pilomatrixoma, somatic, Mosaic variegated aneuploidy syndrome 7 and Gardner syndrome.
The PRY2 gene is associated with Y-linked inheritance, male infertility and azoospermia.
The KRIT1 gene is linked to various vascular abnormalities and diseases, including retinal and hepatic vascular malformations.
Maternally imprinted autosomal dominant gene associated with Bridgman Syndrome.
The ANAPC1 gene is associated with calcinosis in multiple organ syndrome (MOS).
LMOD2 is a gene that encodes a protein involved in muscle function. Mutations in this gene have been linked to various cardiac disorders and muscular dystrophies.
PLOD3 gene mutation is linked to Osteogenesis Imperativa Condylasa type 2, also known as Collett's disease.

The SMARCB1 gene is a tumor suppressor gene, and mutations in this gene have been associated with various diseases and abnormalities, including midface hypoplasia, obesity, developmental delay, neonatal hypotonia, and broad lateral eyebrows. The SMARCB1 gene is also known for its involvement in the development of certain types of cancer, such as malignant rhabdoid tumors.
This gene is also linked to Unclassified myelodysplastic syndrome according to ORPHA.
The IL12A-AS1 gene is associated with the disease Fountain syndrome, which is characterized by papules on the skin.

diseases: Partial duplication of the phalanges of the hallux
comment: The NEK1 gene is associated with a range of skeletal abnormalities and diseases, including hallux-related issues, polydactyly, adactyly, cleft lip/palate, shortening of limbs, and deformities.

symptoms: Aplasia/Hypoplasia involving bones of the thorax
Early ossification of capital femoral epiphyses
comment: The ARID1A gene is associated with CSPP1, a rare genetic disorder characterized by a range of skeletal abnormalities and other features.
Tuberous Sclerosis Complex 1 gene is associated with an increased risk of developing certain types of neoplasms and congenital anomalies.

The UROD gene encodes the uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase enzyme, which is involved in the final step of heme synthesis. Mutations in this gene can lead to defects in heme production, resulting in the accumulation of toxic intermediates and the development of various porphyrias.

diseases: Neuropathy, hereditary sensory and autonomic, type IIB
Mandibuloacral dysplasia with type B lipodystrophy
comment: The RETREG1 gene is associated with various symptoms and diseases, including acroosteolysis of distal phalanges (feet), neuropathy, mandibuloacral dysplasia, and severe lipodystrophic laminopathy.
This gene is associated with ADPKD and NPHP3-related Meckel-like syndrome, both of which are characterized by abnormal biliary tract morphology.

diseases: Generalized non-convulsive status epilepticus without coma
symptoms: Generalized non-convulsive status epilepticus without coma
comment: POLG gene mutations can lead to a range of symptoms and abnormalities, including epilepsy, neurological degeneration, and abnormal nucleobase concentrations. The exact mechanism is not fully understood but it is believed that the mutation affects the function of thymidine phosphorylase, an enzyme involved in pyrimidine metabolism.
IL12A-AS1 has been linked to Venous thrombosis, Thoracic outlet syndrome and Idiopathic steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome
None of the comments are given for this gene.

The NCF1 gene provides instructions for making a protein that helps guide the migration of cells during tooth development. Mutations in the NCF1 gene have been identified as the cause of hypodontia, which is characterized by the absence or severe reduction of one or more teeth.
Sh3pcd2b gene is associated with Buphthalmos (expansion of the eyeball) and Glaucoma 3, a primary congenital form of glaucoma.
Association with Broad metatarsal and Smith-McCort dysplasia

diseases: Juvenile type ovarian granulosa cell tumor
Deaf blind hypopigmentation syndrome, Yemenite type
symptoms: Abnormal size of the palpebral fissures
comment: This gene is associated with Abnormal size of the palpebral fissures and Deaf blind hypopigmentation syndrome, Yemenite type
TP53 is a tumor suppressor gene that plays a crucial role in preventing cancer. Mutations or alterations in this gene have been linked to various types of cancer, including nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

diseases: Ankyloblepharon filiforme adnatum and cleft palate
comment: KIF7 gene is linked to several diseases including gastric cancer, Van der Woude syndrome, Orofacial cleft 1, Acrofrontofacionasal dysostosis 1 and Ankyloblepharon filiforme adnatum and cleft palate.

gene: multiple genes associated with intestinal polyposis, but some of the most notable ones are
comment: The exact genes linked to these diseases and symptoms are not explicitly mentioned in the provided associations. However, some of the genes associated with intestinal polyposis include APC, MSH2, MLH1, MTHFR, and others. The specific gene(s) responsible for GIST-plus syndrome, Cronkhite-Canada syndrome, and benign schwannoma are not specified here.

The COL7A1 gene is a crucial component in the production of collagen type VII, which plays a significant role in skin elasticity and strength. Mutations or defects in this gene can lead to premature skin wrinkling and elastoderma.

This gene encodes for the common gamma-chain (c) of several cytokine receptors, including those for IL-2, IL-4, IL-7, IL-9, and IL-15. Mutations in this gene can lead to impaired immune function and increased susceptibility to viral infections.

The KCNJ18 gene provides instructions for making a protein called Kir2.1. This protein is part of a channel that helps regulate the amount of potassium ions in cells. Mutations in the KCNJ18 gene have been identified as the cause of Hyperaldosteronism, familial, type III, which is characterized by low levels of potassium in the blood (hypokalemia).

diseases: Muscular dystrophy-dystroglycanopathy (congenital with brain and eye anomalies), type A
comment: The gene LAMP3 is linked to the symptoms, abnormalities, and diseases mentioned above. It's worth noting that the OMIM numbers provided in the associations refer to unique identifiers for each disease or condition, which can help facilitate research and understanding of these conditions.

PLA2G7 is the gene that codes for the enzyme platelet-activating factor acetylhydrolase. Mutations in this gene have been linked to abnormal levels of platelet-activating factor, which can lead to various symptoms and diseases.

DNAJB13 is a gene associated with several intestinal disorders. Intestinal malrotation and volvulus are conditions where the intestine twists abnormally, leading to bowel obstruction. Martinez-Frias syndrome and Emanuel syndrome are rare genetic disorders that affect the development of the intestines.

CHCHD10 is a gene associated with Oculo-palato-cerebral syndrome and global brain atrophy. The exact function of this gene is not well understood but it has been linked to several neurological disorders.

diseases: Atresia of the external auditory canal
symptoms: external auditory canal atresia (blockage of the ear canal)
female pseudohermaphroditism (developmental disorder of sex characteristics)
bilateral renal agenesis (absence of both kidneys)
ureteral agenesis (absence of one or both ureters)
comment: FREM2 stands for 'facial dysmorphia type II', a rare genetic disorder caused by mutations in the PITX2 gene. The PITX2 gene provides instructions for making a protein that plays a crucial role in the development of various organs and tissues, including the heart, lungs, kidneys, and reproductive system.

symptoms: Focal sensory seizure with visual features
comment: Association between NHLRC1 gene and familial adult myoclonic epilepsy, epilepsy
JAGN1 gene mutation is associated with Alagille Syndrome 1, which affects the liver and other organs.
The GNAS gene provides instructions for making a protein called Gs, which is part of a larger complex that helps regulate the activity of cells in the body.

diseases: FLCN (Familial Lung Cancer 2), Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation
comment: Mutations in the SPG20 gene are associated with autosomal recessive proximal spinal muscular atrophy and FLCN, a rare familial lung cancer syndrome. The same mutations also cause congenital pulmonary airway malformation (CPAM) in newborns.
A gene mutation is believed to be the cause of episodic pain syndromes. LEMD3 mutations lead to altered protein structure, which may affect the nerves' function.

The RNU4ATAC gene is associated with Hypomyelinating leukodystrophy, a rare and serious genetic disorder that affects the growth of myelin, the fatty substance that surrounds and protects nerve fibers. The symptoms of this condition can include prominent eyelashes, among others.

diseases: B-cell expansion with NFKB and T-cell anergy
Reduced tissue fatty aldehyde dehydrogenase activity
comment: Association with various ocular abnormalities and diseases.

The ARX gene is associated with Duane anomaly, a congenital disorder that affects the muscles of the ear and can lead to hearing loss, balance problems, and other complications. Additionally, it has been linked to 8q12 microduplication syndrome, a genetic disorder characterized by an extra copy of part of the long arm of chromosome 8.
The VAC14 gene encodes a transcriptional repressor protein that plays a critical role in regulating the expression of genes involved in bone development and metabolism.

diseases: Polycystic liver disease 4 with or without kidney cysts
Polycystic liver disease 3 with or without kidney cysts
comment: NEK8 gene mutations are associated with polycystic liver diseases, including hepatic and renal cysts.
Gene SLC6A18 is involved in the transport of neutral amino acids. Mutations in this gene can lead to impaired function, resulting in Iminoglycinuria and Hydroxyprolinemia.

GDF6 is a gene that has been linked to multiple genetic disorders, including abnormalities of the nervous system. It affects various aspects of cognition and motor skills, such as spatial visualization, aptitude for motion, cognitive function in social settings.

symptoms: Radial deviation of the hand or of fingers of the hand
comment: A gene that is associated with various congenital abnormalities and diseases, including pulmonary fibrosis.

diseases: Absent anterior chamber of the eye
Visual acuity light perception with projection
comment: The LRP5 gene is a critical regulator of bone homeostasis and has been associated with several skeletal disorders. Mutations in the LRP5 gene have been linked to a range of conditions, including Sclerotic vertebral body, Metacarpal diaphyseal endosteal sclerosis, Absent anterior chamber of the eye, Abnormal lower limb bone morphology, and Visual acuity light perception with projection.

RUNX1 mutations are associated with Greenberg dysplasia, a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of blood cells. Abnormalities in white blood cell morphology are a common feature of this condition.
Several studies have associated ARID1A mutations with these conditions, which are characterized by abnormalities in the mesentery, renal anomalies, and other systemic features.

diseases: Short metacarpals with rounded proximal ends
comment: Achondroplasia-like condition

diseases: Mitochondrial complex III deficiency, nuclear type 11
comment: Multiple genes are linked to these conditions.

Decreased unswitched memory B cell proportion
comment: POLD3 gene mutations associated with immunodeficiency and abnormalities in immune cell function
The gene IL31RA is linked to Cutaneous amyloidosis.
Multiple genetic syndromes associated with the gene PTPN11, encoding a protein tyrosine phosphatase.

diseases: Triangular shaped distal phalanges of the hand
comment: PITX2 gene mutations are associated with several congenital heart defects and syndromes.
TTBK2 gene is associated with Spinocerebellar ataxia type 11 and Jerky ocular pursuit movements.

symptoms: Hair abnormalities (e.g. slow-growing, abnormal color, shape, or distribution) on the scalp, pubic area, axillary region
Nail abnormalities (e.g. thickening, brittleness, or pitting)
comment: KRT74 is a gene that codes for a protein involved in skin structure and function. Mutations in this gene have been linked to various skin-related disorders, including those affecting hair growth and development.
A genetic disorder associated with hypertrophic scars (labial hypertrophy) and abdominal wall defects.

diseases: Focal facial dermal dysplasia 1, Brauer type

comment: Association with non-medullary thyroid carcinoma (OMIM:Thyroid cancer, nonmedullary) and Steinert myotonic dystrophy (ORPHA).
Mutations in the PITX2 gene are associated with Tibial Dysplasia, Narrow Iliac Wing Syndrome (NIWS), and Long Fibula Syndrome.

symptoms: Functional abnormality of the gastrointestinal tract
comment: Both conditions are linked to abnormalities in the SEMA3D gene.

Glycogen storage disease with severe cardiomyopathy due to glycogenin deficiency

A protein-coding gene that encodes a component of the transcriptional activator complex.
Sodium-potassium-chloride cotransporter 3 (NCC) gene

Glucosaminidase alpha (GAL) deficiency is a rare genetic disorder that affects the cornea, causing it to become clouded and discolored. The GLA gene provides instructions for making an enzyme called glucosaminidase alpha, which helps break down glucose in the cornea.
GSX2 gene mutations have been associated with abnormal basal ganglia morphology and sub-cortical nodular heterotopia, which may lead to various neurological disorders.
KCNJ10 gene mutations are associated with Bartter syndrome type 2, a rare genetic disorder characterized by an abnormality in the kidney's ability to reabsorb sodium, potassium, and chloride.

diseases: Camptodactyly, tall stature, and hearing loss syndrome
comment: SCARF2 gene is associated with various skeletal abnormalities and diseases including multicentric osteolysis, nodulosis, and arthropathy, arthrogryposis, distal, type 3, camptodactyly, tall stature, and hearing loss syndrome.

gene: Multiple genes, refer to individual OMIM entries for details.

Global developmental delay, lung cysts, overgrowth, and wilms tumor
Neurodevelopmental disorder with impaired intellectual development, hypotonia, and ataxia
Neurodevelopmental disorder with microcephaly, hypotonia, nystagmus, and seizures
